children.definition: Material used as a raw material for the manufacture of structural clay products, i.e. Bricks, pipes and tiles.

children.label: acid mine drainage
children.definition: Mine drainage that has a pH value of less than 7.0.

children.label: aqueous liquid emission
children.definition: Emission of liquids in which water is the most abundant constituent.

children.label: basic mine drainage
children.definition: Mine drainage that has a pH value of greater than 7.0.

children.label: collapse
children.definition: Collapse of surface material into underground excavations, resulting in major surface subsidence and disruption.

children.label: dam failure
children.definition: Breach or destruction of a large water or tailing containment structure and release of contained water that could result in downstream damage or pollution.

children.label: dust
children.definition: Emission of dust into the air. Dust is defines as small solid particles with a diameter less than 75 µm. The particles are small enough to remain suspended in the air for some time, but settle out under their own weight in still air.

children.label: emission
children.definition: Any release or disposal of a substance into the environment

children.label: erosion
children.definition: Impact due to loss of material shaped by mining activities through water or wind action.

children.label: gaseous emission
children.definition: Emission of gaseous substance, including steam or release of gas resulting from mining activity.

children.label: habitat modification
children.definition: Impact due to modification of landscape and ecosystem on or adjacent to the resource extraction site.

children.label: health impact
children.definition: Resource extraction activity directly or indirectly impacts the health of living organisms (human, other animals, plants...)

children.label: heat
children.definition: Impact includes noticable thermal release from mining activity (e.g. warm water discharge, exothermic mineral reactions).

children.label: instability
children.definition: Increased propensity for unpredictable surface displacements

children.label: landslide
children.definition: Downslope displacement of material due to excavation related to resource extraction. Includes slope failure on waste or tailings heaps.

children.label: liquid emission
children.definition: Emission of liquids from resource extraction site; principal concern is likely to be toxic chemical constituents in the liquids, but these are too varied to enumerate in this vocabulary

children.label: mine drainage
children.definition: Surface discharge of aqueous liquid that has interacted with mineralized rock disturbed by Earth Resource extraction activities

children.label: mineral fiber emission
children.definition: Emission of mineral fiber particulates that are threats to respiratory health.

children.label: neutral mine drainage
children.definition: Mine drainage that has a pH value of 7.0.

children.label: noise
children.definition: Noticable sound resulting from a mining activity, usually from machinery, processing plant or blasting.

children.label: non-aqueous liquid emission
children.definition: Emission of liquid in which water is not the most abundant constituent.

children.label: odour
children.definition: Impact includes unpleasant smell resulting from a mining activity.

children.label: particulate emission
children.definition: Emission of suspended particulate material into the air or water

children.label: physical impact
children.definition: Impact due to direct physical effects of natural processes resulting from mining activity.

children.label: radiation
children.definition: Emission on air of radionuclides substance gangerous for many health situation

children.label: radioactive emission
children.definition: Emission of radioactive material or energy radiation due to radioactive decay of uncoverning of minerals.

children.label: runoff water
children.definition: Surface discharge of aqueous liquid sourced by rainfall that has not interacted with mineralized rock.

children.label: sedimentation
children.definition: Deposition of sediment eroded from resource extraction site in undesirable locations

children.label: subsidence
children.definition: Settlement of land or soil through compaction of loose or excavated material

children.label: subsurface aqueous liquid discharge
children.definition: Impact of subsurface aqueous fluid emission in which liquid water is the most abundant constituent.

children.label: surface aqueous liquid discharge
children.definition: Impact of aqueous liquid emission into the subsurface.

children.label: vibration
children.definition: Ground and airborne vibration (airblast) caused by resource extraction activity or by transportation associated with the mining activity or related transportation" (eg large lorries through narrow village roads).

children.label: visual disturbance
children.definition: Impact due to changed view, scene or visual appearance that modifies landscape resulting from mining activity.

children.label: abandoned river channel setting
children.definition: A drainage channel along which runoff no longer occurs, as on an alluvial fan

children.label: above carbonate compensation depth setting
children.definition: Marine environment in which carbonate sediment does not dissolve before reaching the sea floor and can accumulate.

children.label: abyssal setting
children.definition: The ocean environment at water depths between 3500 and 6000 metres

children.label: active continental margin setting
children.definition: Plate margin setting on continental crust.

children.label: active spreading center setting
children.definition: Divergent plate margin at which new oceanic crust is being formed

children.label: aeolian process setting
children.definition: Sedimentary setting in which wind is the dominant process producing, transporting, and depositing sediment. Typically has low-relief plain or piedmont slope physiography.

children.label: algal flat setting
children.definition: Modern algal flats are found on rock or mud in areas flooded only by the highest tides and are often subject to high evaporation rates. Algal flats survive only when an area is salty enough to eliminate snails and other herbivorous animals that eat algae, yet is not so salty that the algae cannot survive. The most common species of algae found on algal flats are blue-green algae of the genera Scytonema and Schizothrix. These algae can tolerate the daily extremes in temperature and oxygen that typify conditions on the flats. Other plants sometimes found on algal flats include one-celled green algae, flagellates, diatoms, bacteria, and isolated scrubby red and black mangroves, as well as patches of saltwort. Animals include false cerith, cerion snails, fiddler crabs, and great land crabs. Flats with well developed algal mats are restricted for the most part to the Keys, with Sugarloaf and Crane Keys offering prime examples of algal flat habitat. (Audubon, 1991)

children.label: alluvial fan setting
children.definition: A low, outspread, relatively flat to gently sloping mass of loose rock material, shaped like an open fan or a segment of a cone, deposited by a stream (esp. in a semiarid region) at the place where it issues from a narrow mountain valley upon a plain or broad valley, or where a tributary stream is near or at its junction with the main stream, or wherever a constriction in a valley abruptly ceases or the gradient of the stream suddenly decreases, it is steepest near the mouth of the valley where its apex points upstream, and it slopes gently and convexly outward with gradually decreasing gradient

children.label: alluvial plain setting
children.definition: An assemblage landforms produced by alluvial and fluvial processes (braided streams, terraces, etc.) that form low gradient, regional ramps along the flanks of mountains and extend great distances from their sources (e.g.high Plains of North America). (NRCS GLOSSARY OF LANDFORM AND GEOLOGIC TERMS). A level or gently sloping tract or a slightly undulating land surface produced by extensive deposition of alluvium... Synonym-- wash plain,...river plain, aggraded valley plain,... (Jackson, 1997, p. 17). May include one or more River plain systems.

children.label: anoxic setting
children.definition: Setting depleted in oxygen, typically subaqueous.

children.label: arid or semi arid environment setting
children.definition: Setting characterized by mean annual precipitation of 10 inches (25 cm) or less. (Jackson, 1997, p. 172). Equivalent to SLTT 'Desert setting', but use 'Arid' to emphasize climatic nature of setting definition.

children.label: back arc setting
children.definition: Tectonic setting adjacent to a volcanic arc formed above a subduction zone. The back arc setting is on the opposite side of the volcanic arc from the trench at which oceanic crust is consumed in a subduction zone. Back arc setting includes terrane that is affected by plate margin and arc-related processes.

children.label: backreef setting
children.definition: The landward side of a reef. The term is often used adjectivally to refer to deposits within the restricted lagoon behind a barrier reef, such as the back-reef facies of lagoonal deposits. In some places, as on a platform-edge reef tract, back reef refers to the side of the reef away from the open sea, even though no land may be nearby

children.label: barrier beach setting
children.definition: A narrow, elongate sand or gravel ridge rising slightly above the high-tide level and extending generally parallel with the shore, but separated from it by a lagoon (Shepard, 1954, p.1904), estuary, or marsh, it is extended by longshore transport and is rarely more than several kilometers long.

children.label: barrier island coastline setting
children.definition: setting meant to include all the various geographic elements typically associated with a barrier island coastline, including the barrier islands, and geomorphic/geographic elements that are linked by processes associated with the presence of the island (e.g. wash over fans, inlet channel, back barrier lagoon).

children.label: barrier lagoon setting
children.definition: A lagoon that is roughly parallel to the coast and is separated from the open ocean by a strip of land or by a barrier reef. Tidal influence is typically restricted and the lagoon is commonly hypersaline.

children.label: basin bog setting
children.definition: An ombrotrophic or ombrogene peat/bog whose nutrient supply is exclusively from rain water (including snow and atmospheric fallout) therefore making nutrients extremely oligotrophic

children.label: basin plain setting
children.definition: Near flat areas of ocean floor, slope less than 1:1000, generally receive only distal turbidite and pelagic sediments.

children.label: bathyal setting
children.definition: The ocean environment at water depths between 200 and 3500 metres

children.label: beach setting
children.definition: The unconsolidated material at the shoreline that covers a gently sloping zone, typically with a concave profile, extending landward from the low-water line to the place where there is a definite change in material or physiographic form (such as a cliff), or to the line of permanent vegetation (usually the effective limit of the highest storm waves), at the shore of a body of water, formed and washed by waves or tides, usually covered by sand or gravel, and lacking a bare rocky surface.

children.label: below carbonate compensation depth setting
children.definition: Marine environment in which water is deep enough that carbonate sediment goes into solution before it can accumulate on the sea floor.

children.label: biological reef setting
children.definition: A ridgelike or moundlike structure, layered or massive, built by sedentary calcareous organisms, esp. corals, and consisting mostly of their remains, it is wave-resistant and stands topographically above the surrounding contemporaneously deposited sediment.

children.label: blanket bog
children.definition: Topogeneous bog/peat whose moisture content is largely dependent on surface water. It is relatively rich in plant nutrients, nitrogen, and mineral matter, is mildly acidic to nearly neutral, and contains little or no cellulose, forms in topographic depressions with essential stagnat or non-moving minerotrophic water supply

children.label: bog setting
children.definition: Waterlogged, spongy ground, consisting primarily of mosses, containing acidic, decaying vegetation that may develop into peat.

children.label: braided river channel setting
children.definition: A stream that divides into or follows an interlacing or tangled network of several small branching and reuniting shallow channels separated from each other by ephemeral branch islands or channel bars, resembling in plan the strands of a complex braid. Such a stream is generally believed to indicate an inability to carry all of its load, such as an overloaded and aggrading stream flowing in a wide channel on a floodplain

children.label: carbonate dominated shoreline setting
children.definition: A shoreline setting in which terrigenous input is minor compared to local carbonate sediment production. Constructional biogenic activity is an important element in geomorphic development.

children.label: cave setting
children.definition: A natural underground open space, it generally has a connection to the surface, is large enough for a person to enter, and extends into darkness. The most common type of cave is formed in limestone by dissolution.

children.label: coastal dune field setting
children.definition: A dune field on low-lying land recently abandoned or built up by the sea, the dunes may ascend a cliff and travel inland.

children.label: coastal plain setting
children.definition: A low relief plain bordering a water body extending inland to the nearest elevated land, sloping very gently towards the water body. Distinguished from alluvial plain by presence of relict shoreline-related deposits or morphology.

children.label: collisional setting
children.definition: Tectonic setting in which two continental crustal plates impact and are sutured together after intervening oceanic crust is entirely consumed at a subduction zone separating the plates. Such collision typically involves major mountain forming events, exemplified by the modern Alpine and Himalayan mountain chains.

children.label: contact metamorphic setting
children.definition: Metamorphism of country rock at the contact of an igneous body.

children.label: continental borderland setting
children.definition: An area of the continental margin between the shoreline and the continental slope that is topographically more complex than the continental shelf. It is characterized by ridges and basins, some of which are below the depth of the continental shelf. An example is the southern California continental borderland,.... (Jackson, 1997, p. 138)..

children.label: continental crustal setting
children.definition: That type of the Earth's crust which underlies the continents and the continental shelves, it is equivalent to the sial and continental sima and ranges in thickness from about 25 km to more than 70 km under mountain ranges, averaging ~40 km. The density of the continental crust averages ~2.8 g/cm3 and is ~2.7 g.cm3 in the upper layer. The velocities of compressional seismic waves through it average ~6.5 km/s and are less than ~7.0 km/sec.

children.label: continental rift setting
children.definition: Extended terrane in a zone of continental breakup, may include incipient oceanic crust. Examples include Red Sea, East Africa Rift, Salton Trough

children.label: continental shelf setting
children.definition: That part of the ocean floor that is between the shoreline and the continental slope (or, when there is no noticeable continental slope, a depth of 200 m). It is characterized by its gentle slope of 0.1 degree (Jackson, 1997, p. 138). Continental shelves have a classic shoreline-shelf-slope profile termed 'clinoform'.

children.label: crustal setting
children.definition: The outermost layer or shell of the Earth, defined according to various criteria, including seismic velocity, density and composition, that part of the Earth above the Mohorovicic discontinuity, made up of the sial and the sima.

children.label: cutoff meander setting
children.definition: The abandoned, bow- or horseshoe-shaped channel of a former meander, left when the stream formed a cutoff across a narrow meander neck. Note that these are typically lakes, thus also lacustrine.

children.label: deep sea trench setting
children.definition: Deep ocean basin with steep (average 10 degrees) slope toward land, more gentle slope (average 5 degrees) towards the sea, and abundant seismic activity on landward side of trench. Does not denote water depth, but may be very deep.

children.label: delta distributary channel setting
children.definition: A divergent stream flowing away from the main stream and not returning to it, as in a delta or on an alluvial plain

children.label: delta distributary mouth setting
children.definition: The mouth of a delta distributary channel where fluvial discharge moves from confined to unconfined flow conditions

children.label: delta front setting
children.definition: A narrow zone where deposition in deltas is most active, consisting of a continuous sheet of sand, and occurring within the effective depth of wave erosion (10 m or less). It is the zone separating the prodelta from the delta plain, and it may or may not be steep\

children.label: delta plain setting
children.definition: The level or nearly level surface composing the landward part of a large or compound delta, strictly, an alluvial plain characterized by repeated channel bifurcation and divergence, multiple distributary channels, and interdistributary flood basins

children.label: deltaic system setting
children.definition: Environments at the mouth of a river or stream that enters a standing body of water (ocean or lake). The delta forms a triangular or fan-shaped plain of considerable area. Subaerial parts of the delta are crossed by many distributaries of the main river, and commonly extend beyond the general trend of the coast. Subaqueous parts of the delta merge with the adjacent basin floor, and are progressively influenced by non-fluvial processes. Deltas result from the accumulation of sediment supplied by the river in such quantities that it is not removed by tides, waves, and currents. Adapted from the Glossary of Geology definition for delta (Jackson, 1997, p. 167).

children.label: dunefield setting
children.definition: Extensive deposits on sand in an area where the supply is abundant. As a characteristic, individual dunes somewhat resemble barchans but are highly irregular in shape and crowded, erg areas of the Sahara are an example.

children.label: earth interior setting
children.definition: Geologic environments within the solid Earth.

children.label: earth surface setting
children.definition: Geologic environments on the surface of the solid Earth. Hierarchy presented here is based on assumption that a particular setting may be specified by a combination of a climatic setting with one or more process or geomorphically defined settings..

children.label: englacial setting
children.definition: Contained, embedded, or carried within the body of a glacier or ice sheet, said of meltwater streams, till, drift, moraine

children.label: epicontinental marine setting
children.definition: Marine setting situated within the interior of the continent, rather than at the edge of a continent.

children.label: estuarine delta setting
children.definition: A delta that has filled, or is in the process of filling, an estuary

children.label: estuarine lagoon setting
children.definition: A lagoon produced by the temporary sealing of a river estuary by a storm barrier. Such lagoons are usually seasonal and exist until the river breaches the barrier, they occur in regions of low or spasmodic rainfall

children.label: estuary setting
children.definition: Environments at the seaward end or the widened funnel-shaped tidal mouth of a river valley where fresh water comes into contact with seawater and where tidal effects are evident (adapted from Glossary of Geology, Jackson, 1997, p. 217).

children.label: extended terrane setting
children.definition: Tectonic setting characterized by extension of the upper crust manifested by formation of rift valleys or basin and range physiography, with arrays of low to high angle normal faults. Modern examples include the North Sea, East Africa, and the Basin and Range of the North American Cordillera. Typically applied in continental crustal settings.

children.label: extra terrestrial setting
children.definition: Material originated outside of the Earth or its atmosphere.

children.label: fast spreading center setting
children.definition: Spreading center at which the opening rate is greater than 100 mm per year.

children.label: floodplain setting
children.definition: The surface or strip of relatively smooth land adjacent to a river channel, constructed by the present river in its existing regimen and covered with water when the river overflows its banks. It is built of alluvium carried by the river during floods and deposited in the sluggish water beyond the influence of the swiftest current. A river has one floodplain and may have one or more terraces representing abandoned floodplains

children.label: forearc setting
children.definition: Tectonic setting between a subduction-related trench and a volcanic arc

children.label: foreland setting
children.definition: The exterior area of an orogenic belt where deformation occurs without significant metamorphism. Generally the foreland is closer to the continental interior than other portions of the orogenic belt are.

children.label: forereef setting
children.definition: The seaward side of a reef, the slope covered with deposits of coarse reef talus

children.label: gibber plain setting
children.definition: A desert plain strewn with wind-abraded pebbles, or gibbers, a gravelly desert.

children.label: glacial outwash plain setting
children.definition: Areas adjacent to glacial front dominated by sediment and water supplied by glacial melting.

children.label: glacier lateral setting
children.definition: Settings adjacent to edges of confined glacier.

children.label: glacier related setting
children.definition: Earth surface setting with geography defined by spatial relationship to glaciers (e.g. on top of a glacier, next to a glacier, in front of a glacier...). Processes related to moving ice dominate sediment transport and deposition and landform development. Includes subaqueous, shoreline, and terrestrial settings that are impacted by the presence of glaciers. Considered a geographically defined setting in that a glacier is a geographic feature.

children.label: glacier terminus setting
children.definition: Region of sediment deposition due to melting of glacier ice. ablation and flow till setting.

children.label: hadal setting
children.definition: The deepest oceanic environment, i.e., over 6000 m in depth. Always in deep sea trench.

children.label: high pressure low temperature earth interior setting
children.definition: High pressure environment characterized by geothermal gradient significantly lower than standard continental geotherm, enviornment in which blueschist facies metamorphic rocks form. Typically associated with subduction zones.

children.label: hillslope setting
children.definition: Earth surface setting characterized by surface slope angles high enough that gravity alone becomes a significant factor in geomorphic development, as well as base-of-slope areas influenced by hillslope processes. Hillslope activities include creep, sliding, slumping, falling, and other downslope movements caused by slope collapse induced by gravitational influence on earth materials. May be subaerial or subaqueous.

children.label: hinterland tectonic setting
children.definition: Tectonic setting in the internal part of an orogenic belt, characterized by plastic deformation of rocks accompanied by significant metamorphism, typically involving crystalline basement rocks. Typically denotes the most structurally thickened part of an orogenic belt, between a magmatic arc or collision zone and a more 'external' foreland setting.

children.label: hot spot setting
children.definition: Setting in a zone of high heat flow from the mantle. Typically identified in intraplate settings, but hot spot may also interact with active plate margins (Iceland...). Includes surface manifestations like volcanic center, but also includes crust and mantle manifestations as well.

children.label: humid temperate climatic setting
children.definition: Setting with seasonal climate having hot to cold or humid to arid seasons.

children.label: humid tropical climatic setting
children.definition: Setting with hot humid climate influenced by equatorial air masses, no winter season.

children.label: hypabyssal setting
children.definition: Igneous environment close to the Earth's surface, characterized by more rapid cooling than plutonic setting to produce generally fine-grained intrusive igneous rock that is commonly associated with co-magmatic volcanic rocks.

children.label: inactive spreading center setting
children.definition: Setting on oceanic crust formed at a spreading center that has been abandoned.

children.label: inner neritic setting
children.definition: The ocean environment at depths between low tide level and 30 metres

children.label: interdistributary bay setting
children.definition: A pronounced indentation of the delta front between advancing stream distributaries, occupied by shallow water, and either open to the sea or partly enclosed by minor distributaries

children.label: intertidal setting
children.definition: Pertaining to the benthic ocean environment or depth zone between high water and low water, also, pertaining to the organisms of that environment

children.label: intraplate tectonic setting
children.definition: Tectonically stable setting far from any active plate margins.

children.label: lacustrine delta setting
children.definition: The low, nearly flat, alluvial tract of land at or near the mouth of a river, commonly forming a triangular or fan-shaped plain of considerable area, crossed by many distributaries of the main river, perhaps extending beyond the general trend of the lake shore, resulting from the accumulation of sediment supplied by the river in such quantities that it is not removed by waves or currents. Most deltas are partly subaerial and partly below water.

children.label: lacustrine setting
children.definition: Setting associated with a lake. Always overlaps with terrestrial, may overlap with subaerial, subaqueous, or shoreline.

children.label: lagoonal setting
children.definition: A shallow stretch of salt or brackish water, partly or completely separated from a sea or lake by an offshore reef, barrier island, sand or spit (Jackson, 1997). Water is shallow, tidal and wave-produced effects on sediments, strong light reaches sediment..

children.label: low energy shoreline setting
children.definition: Settings characterized by very low surface slope and proximity to shoreline. Generally within peritidal setting, but characterized by low surface gradients and generally low-energy sedimentary processes.

children.label: low pressure high temperature setting
children.definition: Setting characterized by temperatures significantly higher that those associated with normal continental geothermal gradient.

children.label: lower bathyal setting
children.definition: The ocean environment at depths between 1000 and 3500 metres

children.label: lower continental crustal setting
children.definition: Continental crustal setting characterized by upper amphibolite to granulite facies metamorphism, insitu melting, residual anhydrous metamorphic rocks, and ductile flow of rock bodies.

children.label: lower delta plain setting
children.definition: The part of a delta plain which is penetrated by saline water and is subject to tidal processes

children.label: lower mantle setting
children.definition: That part of the mantle that lies below a depth of about 660 km. With increasing depth, density increases from ~4.4 g/cm3-to ~5.6 g/cm3, and velocity of compressional seismic waves increases from ~10.7 km/s to ~13.7 km/s (Dziewonski and Anderson, 1981).

children.label: lower oceanic crustal setting
children.definition: Setting characterized by dominantly intrusive mafic rocks, with sheeted dike complexes in upper part and gabbroic to ultramafic intrusive or metamorphic rocks in lower part.

children.label: mantle setting
children.definition: The zone of the Earth below the crust and above the core, which is divided into the upper mantle and the lower mantle, with a transition zone separating them.

children.label: marginal marine sabkha setting
children.definition: Setting characterized by arid to semi-arid conditions on restricted coastal plains mostly above normal high tide level, with evaporite-saline mineral, tidal-flood, and eolian deposits. Boundaries with intertidal setting and non-tidal terrestrial setting are gradational. (Jackson, 1997, p. 561).

children.label: marine carbonate platform setting
children.definition: A shallow submerged plateau separated from continental landmasses, on which high biological carbonate production rates produce enough sediment to maintain the platform surface near sea level. Grades into atoll as area becomes smaller and ringing coral reefs become more prominent part of the setting.

children.label: marine setting
children.definition: Setting characterized by location under the surface of the sea.

children.label: meandering river channel setting
children.definition: Produced by a mature stream swinging from side to side as it flows across its floodplain or shifts its course laterally toward the convex side of an original curve

children.label: medium rate spreading center setting
children.definition: Spreading center at which the opening rate is between 50 and 100 mm per year.

children.label: mid ocean ridge setting
children.definition: Ocean highland associated with a divergent continental margin (spreading center). Setting is characterized by active volcanism, locally steep reliefhydrothermal activity, and pelagic sedimentation.

children.label: middle bathyal setting
children.definition: The ocean environment at water depths between 600 and 1000 metres

children.label: middle continental crust setting
children.definition: Continental crustal setting characterized by greenschist to upper amphibolite facies metamorphism, plutonic igneous rocks, and ductile deformation.

children.label: middle neritic setting
children.definition: The ocean environment at depths between 30 and 100 metres

children.label: mud flat setting
children.definition: A relatively level area of fine grained material (e.g. silt) along a shore (as in a sheltered estuary or chenier-plain) or around an island, alternately covered and uncovered by the tide or covered by shallow water, and barren of vegetation. Includes most tidal flats, but lacks denotation of tidal influence..

children.label: neritic setting
children.definition: The ocean environment at depths between low-tide level and 200 metres, or between low-tide level and approximately the edge of the continental shelf

children.label: ocean highland setting
children.definition: Broad category for subaqueous marine settings characterized by significant relief above adjacent sea floor.

children.label: oceanic crustal setting
children.definition: That type of the Earth's crust which underlies the ocean basins. The oceanic crust is 5-10 km thick, it has a density of 2.9 g/cm3, and compressional seismic-wave velocities travelling through it at 4-7.2 km/sec. Setting in crust produced by submarine volcanism at a mid ocean ridge.

children.label: oceanic plateau setting
children.definition: Region of elevated ocean crust that commonly rises to within 2-3 km of the surface above an abyssal sea floor that lies several km deeper. Climate and water depths are such that a marine carbonate platform does not develop.

children.label: outer neritic setting
children.definition: The ocean environment at depths between 100 and 200 metres or between low-tide level and approximately the edge of the continental shelf

children.label: passive continental margin setting
children.definition: Boundary of continental crust into oceanic crust of an oceanic basin that is not a subduction zone or transform fault system. Generally is rifted margin formed when ocean basin was initially formed.

children.label: pediment setting
children.definition: A gently sloping erosional surface developed at the foot of a receding hill or mountain slope. The surface may be essentially bare, exposing earth material that extends beneath adjacent uplands, or it may be thinly mantled with alluvium and colluvium, ultimately in transit from upland front to basin or valley lowland. In hill-foot slope terrain the mantle is designated \pedisediment.\ The term has been used in several geomorphic contexts: Pediments may be classed with respect to (a) landscape positions, for example, intermontane-basin piedmont or valley-border footslope surfaces (respectively, apron and terrace pediments (Cooke and Warren, 1973)), (b) type of material eroded, bedrock or regolith, or (c) combinations of the above. Compare - Piedmont slope..

children.label: piedmont slope system setting
children.definition: Location on gentle slope at the foot of a mountain, generally used in terms of intermontane-basin terrain. Main components include: (a) An erosional surface on bedrock adjacent to the receding mountain front (pediment, rock pediment), (b) A constructional surface comprising individual alluvial fans and interfan valleys, also near the mountain front, and (c) A distal complex of coalescent fans (bajada), and alluvial slopes without fan form. Piedmont slopes grade to basin-floor depressions with alluvial and temporary lake plains or to surfaces associated with through drainage.

children.label: plate margin setting
children.definition: Tectonic setting at the boundary between two tectonic plates.

children.label: plate spreading center setting
children.definition: Tectonic setting where new oceanic crust is being or has been formed at a divergent plate boundary. Includes active and inactive spreading centers.

children.label: playa setting
children.definition: The usually dry and nearly level plain that occupies the lowest parts of closed depressions, such as those occurring on intermontane basin floors. Temporary flooding occurs primarily in response to precipitation-runoff events.

children.label: polar climatic setting
children.definition: Setting with climate dominated by temperatures below the freezing temperature of water. Includes polar deserts because precipitation is generally scant at high latitude. Climate controlled by arctic air masses, cold dry environment with short summer.

children.label: prodelta setting
children.definition: The part of a delta that is below the effective depth of wave erosion, lying beyond the delta front, and sloping gently down to the floor of the basin into which the delta is advancing and where clastic river sediment ceases to be a significant part of the basin-floor deposits, it is entirely below the water level

children.label: proglacial setting
children.definition: Immediately in front of or just beyond the outer limits of a glacier or ice sheet, generally at or near its lower end, said of lakes, streams, deposits, and other features produced by or derived from the glacier ice

children.label: reef flat setting
children.definition: A stony platform of reef rock, landward of the reef crest at or above the low tide level, occasionally with patches of living coral and associated organisms, and commonly strewn with coral fragments and coral sand. It may include shallow pools, irregular gullies, low islands of sand or rubble (often vegetated, esp. by palms), and scattered colonies of the more hardy species of coral

children.label: regional metamorphic setting
children.definition: Metamorphism not obviously localized along contacts of igneous bodies, includes burial metamorphism and ocean ridge metamorphism

children.label: river channel setting
children.definition: The bed where a natural body of surface water flows or may flow, a natural passageway or depression of perceptible extent containing continuously or periodically flowing water, or forming a connecting link between two bodies of water, a watercourse

children.label: river plain system setting
children.definition: Geologic setting dominated by a river system, river plains may occur in any climatic setting. Includes active channels, abandoned channels, levees, oxbow lakes, flood plain. May be part of an alluvial plain that includes terraces composed of abandoned river plain deposits.

children.label: rocky coast setting
children.definition: Shoreline with significant relief and abundant rock outcrop.

children.label: sand plain setting
children.definition: A sand-covered plain dominated by aeolian processes.

children.label: seamount setting
children.definition: Setting that consists of a conical mountain on the ocean floor (guyot). Typically characterized by active volcanism, pelagic sedimentation. If the mountain is high enough to reach the photic zone, carbonate production may result in reef building to produce a carbonate platform or atoll setting.

children.label: shoreline settings
children.definition: Geologic settings characterized by location adjacent to the ocean or a lake. A zone of indefinite width (may be many kilometers), bordering a body of water that extends from the water line inland to the first major change in landform features. Includes settings that may be subaerial, intermittently subaqueous, or shallow subaqueous, but are intrinsically associated with the interface between land areas and water bodies.

children.label: slope rise setting
children.definition: The part of a subaqueous basin that is between a bordering shelf setting, which separate the basin from an adjacent landmass, and a very low-relief basin plain setting.

children.label: slow spreading center setting
children.definition: Spreading center at which the opening rate is less than 50 mm per year.

children.label: strandplain setting
children.definition: A prograded shore built seaward by waves and currents, and continuous for some distance along the coast. It is characterized by subparallel beach ridges and swales, in places with associated dunes.

children.label: subaerial setting
children.definition: Setting at the interface between the solid earth and the atmosphere, includes some shallow subaqueous settings in river channels and playas. Characterized by conditions and processes, such as erosion, that exist or operate in the open air on or immediately adjacent to the land surface

children.label: subaqueous setting
children.definition: Setting situated in or under permanent, standing water. Used for marine and lacustrine settings, but not for fluvial settings.

children.label: subduction zone setting
children.definition: Tectonic setting at which a tectonic plate, usually oceanic, is moving down into the mantle beneath another overriding plate.

children.label: subglacial setting
children.definition: Formed or accumulated in or by the bottom parts of a glacier or ice sheet, said of meltwater streams, till, moraine, etc.

children.label: submarine fan setting
children.definition: Large fan-shaped cones of sediment on the ocean floor, generally associated with submarine canyons that provide sediment supply to build the fan..

children.label: supraglacial setting
children.definition: Carried upon, deposited from, or pertaining to the top surface of a glacier or ice sheet, said of meltwater streams, till, drift, etc. (Jackson, 1997, p. 639). Dreimanis (1988, p. 39) recommendation that \supraglacial\ supersede \superglacial\ is followed.

children.label: supratidal setting
children.definition: Pertaining to the shore area marginal to the littoral zone, just above high-tide level

children.label: swamp or marsh setting
children.definition: A water-saturated, periodically wet or continually flooded area with the surface not deeply submerged, essentially without the formation of peat. Marshes are characterized by sedges, cattails, rushes, or other aquatic and grasslike vegetation. Swamps are characterized by tree and brush vegetation.

children.label: tectonically defined setting
children.definition: Setting defined by relationships to tectonic plates on or in the Earth.

children.label: terrestrial setting
children.definition: Setting characterized by absence of direct marine influence. Most of the subaerial settings are also terrestrial, but lacustrine settings, while terrestrial, are not subaerial, so the subaerial settings are not included as subcategories.

children.label: tidal channel setting
children.definition: A major channel followed by the tidal currents, extending from offshore into a tidal marsh or a tidal flat.

children.label: tidal flat setting
children.definition: An extensive, nearly horizontal, barren tract of land that is alternately covered and uncovered by the tide, and consisting of unconsolidated sediment (mostly mud and sand). It may form the top surface of a deltaic deposit.

children.label: tidal marsh setting
children.definition: A marsh bordering a coast (as in a shallow lagoon or sheltered bay), formed of mud and of the resistant mat of roots of salt-tolerant plants, and regularly inundated during high tides, a marshy tidal flat.

children.label: tidal setting
children.definition: Setting subject to tidal processes

children.label: transform plate boundary setting
children.definition: Plate boundary at which the adjacent plates are moving laterally relative to each other.

children.label: transitional crustal setting
children.definition: Crust formed in the transition zone between continental and oceanic crust, during the history of continental rifting that culminates in the formation of a new ocean.

children.label: ultra high pressure crustal setting
children.definition: Setting characterized by pressures characteristic of upper mantle, but indicated by mineral assemblage in crustal composition rocks.

children.label: upper bathyal setting
children.definition: The ocean environment at water depths between 200 and 600 metres

children.label: upper continental crustal setting
children.definition: Continental crustal setting dominated by non metamorphosed to low greenschist facies metamorphic rocks, and brittle deformation.

children.label: upper delta plain setting
children.definition: The part of a delta plain essentially unaffected by basinal processes. They do not differ substantially from alluvial environments except that areas of swamp, marsh and lakes are usually more widespread and channels may bifurcate downstream

children.label: upper mantle setting
children.definition: That part of the mantle which lies above a depth of about 660 km and has a density of 3.4 g/cm3 to 4.0 g/cm3 with increasing depth. Similarly, P-wave velocity increases from about 8 to 11 km/sec with depth and S wave velocity increases from about 4.5 to 6 km/sec with depth. It is presumed to be peridotitic in composition. It includes the subcrustal lithosphere the asthenosphere and the transition zone,

children.label: upper oceanic crustal setting
children.definition: Oceanic crustal setting dominated by extrusive rocks, abyssal oceanic sediment, with increasing mafic intrusive rock in lower part.

children.label: volcanic arc setting
children.definition: A generally curvillinear belt of volcanoes above a subduction zone.

children.label: wetland setting
children.definition: Setting characterized by gentle surface slope, and at least intermittent presence of standing water, which may be fresh, brackish, or saline. Wetland may be terrestrial setting or shoreline setting.

children.label: accretion
children.definition: The addition of material to a continent. Typically involves convergent or transform motion.

children.label: alteration
children.definition: General term for any change in the mineralogical or chemical composition of a rock. Typically related to interaction with hydrous fluids.

children.label: biological precipitation
children.definition: The deposition of minerals from solution by the agency of organisms

children.label: biological weathering
children.definition: breakdown of rocks by biological agents, e.g. the penetrating and expanding force of roots, the presence of moss and lichen causing humic acids to be retained in contact with rock, and the work of animals (worms, moles, rabbits) in modifying surface soil

children.label: bolide impact
children.definition: The impact of an extraterrestrial body on the surface of the earth

children.label: chemical precipitation
children.definition: The deposition of mineral matter by precipitation from solution or as a result of chemical reactions. May be sedimentary or hydrothermal.

children.label: chemical weathering
children.definition: The process of weathering by which chemical reactions (hydrolysishydration, oxidation, carbonation, ion exchange, and solution) transform rocks and minerals into new chemical combinations that are stable under conditions prevailing at or near the Earth's surface, e.g. the alteration of orthoclase to kaolinite.

children.label: cometary impact
children.definition: The impact of a comet on the surface of the earth

children.label: contact metamorphism
children.definition: Metamorphism taking place in rocks at or near their contact with a genetically related body of igneous rock

children.label: continental breakup
children.definition: Fragmentation of a continental plate into two or more smaller plates, may involve rifting or strike slip faulting.

children.label: continental collision
children.definition: The amalgamation of two continental plates or blocks along a convergent margin.

children.label: debris flow deposition
children.definition: Laminar high-concentration, generally cohesionless deposition process. Flow types included liquefied flow, fluidized flow, grain flow, traction carpet or modified grain flow.

children.label: deep water oxygen depletion
children.definition: Process of removal of oxygen from from the deep part of a body of water.

children.label: deformation
children.definition: Movement of rock bodies by displacement on fault or shear zones, or change in shape of a body of Earth material.

children.label: deformation twinning
children.definition: Deformation of a crystal by gliding to produce crystallographic twinning.

children.label: deposition
children.definition: Accumulation of material, the constructive process of accumulation of sedimentary particles, chemical precipitation of mineral matter from solution, or the accumulation of organic material on the death of plants and animals.

children.label: deposition from moving fluid
children.definition: Deposition of sediment from moving water or air, in which the sediment is transported by entrainment in the moving fluid. Constrast with debris flow or turbidity current deposition in which movement of fluid/sediment mixture is due to incorporation of sediment in fluid.

children.label: diagenetic process
children.definition: Any chemical, physical, or biological process that affects a sedimentary EarthMaterial after initial deposition, and during or after lithification, exclusive of weathering and metamorphism. [adapt. Jackson, 1997] Example processes include compaction, cementation, authigenesis, replacement, leachinghydration, and bacterial action. Includes processes that are normal in the surficial or outer part of the earth’s crust [Jackson, 1997]. Changes in a deeply buried sedimentary rock may be continuous from diagenesis into recrystallization to form a metamorphic rock. Robertson [1999] defines the boundary between diagenesis and metamorphism in sedimentary rocks as follows: \the boundary between diagenesis and metamorphism is somewhat arbitrary and strongly dependent on the rock types involved. For example changes take place in organic materials at lower temperatures than in rocks dominated by silicate minerals. In mudrocks, a white mica (illite) crystallinity value of less than 0.42D.2U obtained by X-ray diffraction analysis, is used to define the onset of metamorphism (Kisch, 1991). In this scheme, the first appearance of glaucophane, lawsonite, paragonite, prehnite, pumpellyite or stilpnomelane is taken to indicate the lower limit of metamorphism (Frey and Kisch, 1987, Bucher and Frey, 1994, Frey and Robinson, 1998). Most workers agree that such mineral growth starts at 150 ± 50° C in silicate rocks. Many rock types may show no change in mineralogy under these conditions and hence the recognition of the onset of metamorphism will vary with bulk composition.\

children.label: diffusion creep
children.definition: Grain-scale, ductile deformation accomplished by the motion of atoms through crystals, along grain boundaries, and through pore fluids.

children.label: dislocation metamorphism
children.definition: Metamorphism concentrated along narrow belts of shearing or crushing without an appreciable rise in temperature

children.label: dissolution
children.definition: The process of dissolving into a homogenous solution, as when an acidic solution dissolves limestone. In karst, refers to the process of dissolving rock to produce landforms, in contrast to solution, the chemical product of dissolution.

children.label: dissolution creep
children.definition: Deformation by dissolution under the effects of differential stress and its transport to a new location by movement of fluid in the rock body.

children.label: ductile flow
children.definition: deformation without apparent loss of continuity at the scale of observation.

children.label: effusive eruption
children.definition: Eruptions characterized by low volatile content of the erupting magma relative to ambient pressure

children.label: erosion
children.definition: The process of disaggregation of rock and displacement of the resultant particles (sediment) usually by the agents of currents such as, wind, water, or ice by downward or down-slope movement in response to gravity or by living organisms (in the case of bioerosion).

children.label: eruption
children.definition: The ejection of volcanic materials (lava, pyroclasts, and volcanic gases) onto the Earth's surface, either from a central vent or from a fissure or group of fissures

children.label: excavation
children.definition: The removal of material, as in a mining operation

children.label: extinction
children.definition: Process of disappearance of a species or higher taxon, so that it no longer exists anywhere or in the subsequent fossil record.

children.label: faulting
children.definition: The process of fracturing, frictional slip, and displacement accumulation that produces a fault

children.label: folding
children.definition: Deformation in which planar surfaces become regularly curviplanar surfaces with definable limbs (zones of lower curvature) and hinges (zones of higher curvature).

children.label: fracturing
children.definition: The formation of a surface of failure resulting from stress

children.label: frost shattering
children.definition: Propagation of fractures due to expansion of freezing water in intergranular spaces and fractures in a rock body. Result is mechanical disintegration spliitting, or breakup of rock.

children.label: geologic process
children.definition: process that effects the geologic record

children.label: geomagnetic process
children.definition: process that results in change in Earth's magnetic field

children.label: grading
children.definition: Leveling of earth surface by rearrangement of prexisting material

children.label: haloclasty
children.definition: Propagation of fractures in rock due to crytallization of mineral salts (typically sodium chloride) from interstitial water, or volumetrick expansion of salts in capillaries, or hydration pressure of interstitial, trapped salts. Generally results in mechanical disintegration of the rock surface.

children.label: hawaiian eruption
children.definition: Eruption in which great quantities of extremely fluid basaltic lava are poured out, mainly issuing in lava fountains from fissures on the flanks of a volcano. Explosive phenomena are rare, but much spatter and scoria are piled into cones and mounds along the vents. Characteristic of shield volcanoes

children.label: human activity
children.definition: Processes of human modification of the earth to produce geologic features

children.label: hydration
children.definition: The process of absorption of water into the crystal structure of a mineral, thereby changing its volume and fracturing and loosening grains

children.label: hydrolysis
children.definition: A decomposition reaction involving water. In geology, it commonly indicates reaction between silicate minerals and either pure water or aqueous solution. In such reactionsh

children.label: ice erosion
children.definition: Erosion by corrasion or plucking by moving ice.

children.label: intrusion
children.definition: The process of emplacement of magma in pre-existing rock

children.label: magmatic crystallisation
children.definition: The process by which matter becomes crystalline, from a gaseous, fluid, or dispersed state

children.label: magmatic process
children.definition: A process involving melted rock (magma).

children.label: magnetic field reversal
children.definition: A geomagnetic event in which the Earth's magnetic field reverses direction.

children.label: mass wasting
children.definition: the dislodgement and downslope transport of soil and rock material under the direct application of gravitational body stresses. In contrast to other erosion processes, the debris removed by mass wasting is not carried within, on, or under another medium. The mass properties of the material being transported depend on the interaction of the soil and rock particles and on the moisture content.

children.label: mass wasting deposition
children.definition: A general term for the dislodgement and downslope transport of soil and rock material under the direct application of gravitational body stresses. In contrast to other erosion processes, the debris removed by mass wasting is not carried within, on, or under another medium. The mass properties of the material being transported depend on the interaction of the soil and rock particles and on the moisture content. Mass wasting includes slow displacements, such as creep and solifluction, and rapid movements such as rockfalls, rockslides, and cohesive debris flows (Jackson, 1997, p. 392). Includes both subaerial mass-wasting processes and subaqueous mass-wasting processes.

children.label: material transport and deposition
children.definition: Transport and heaping of material, as in a land fill, mine dump, dredging operations

children.label: mechanical deposition
children.definition: Process by which material that is being transported as particles by moving air, water, ice, or other fluid comes to rest and accumulates.

children.label: melting
children.definition: change of state from a solid to a liquid

children.label: metamorphic process
children.definition: Mineralogical, chemical, and structural adjustment of solid rocks to physical and chemical conditions that differ from the conditions under which the rocks in question originated, and are generally been imposed at depth, below the surface zones of weathering and cementation.

children.label: meteorite impact
children.definition: The impact of a meteorite on the surface of the earth

children.label: microfracturing
children.definition: Development of fractures within a single grain or cutting several grains.

children.label: obduction
children.definition: The overthrusting of continental crust by oceanic crust or mantle rocks at a convergent plate boundary.

children.label: organic accumulation
children.definition: Sediment accumulation of biologically produced organic material, as in bog, coal swamps.

children.label: orogenic process
children.definition: Mountain building process.

children.label: oxidation
children.definition: Chemical reaction that involve stripping of electrons from cations. Typicall reactions include converting sulfide minerals to oxide minerals, or increasing the oxidation state of cations in existing oxide minerals. The most commonly observed is the oxidation of Fe

children.label: partial melting
children.definition: Process of melting involving only some of the mineral phases in a rock, to produce a mixture of melt and residual particles.

children.label: physical weathering
children.definition: The process of weathering by which frost action, salt-crystal growth, absorption of water, and other physical processes break down a rock to fragments, involving no chemical change

children.label: plinian eruption
children.definition: An explosive eruption in which a steady, turbulent stream of fragmented magma and magmatic gas is released at a high velocity from a vent. Large volumes of tephra and tall eruption columns are characteristic

children.label: polar wander
children.definition: Process of migration of the axis of the earth's dipole field relative to the rotation axis of the Earth.

children.label: pressure release weathering
children.definition: Propagation of fractures near the surface of solid rock due to expansion related to release of confining pressure when deeply buried rock is unroofed. Fractures typically propagate along surfaces close to and subparallel to the surface of the outcrop.

children.label: pyroclastic eruption
children.definition: Eruption produced by the generation and rapid expansion of a gas phase that disrupts magma, surrounding wall rock or sediment

children.label: rifting
children.definition: Extension of the crust to form one or more long, narrow graben of regional extent.

children.label: sea level change
children.definition: Process of mean sea level changing relative to some datum

children.label: sea level fall
children.definition: Process of mean sea level falling relative to some datum

children.label: sea level rise
children.definition: Process of mean sea level rising relative to some datum

children.label: sedimentary process
children.definition: A phenomenon that changes the distribution or physical properties of sediment at or near the earth's surface

children.label: shearing
children.definition: A deformation in which contiguous parts of a body are displaced relatively to each other in a direction parallel to a surface. The surface may be a discrete fault, or the deformation may be a penetrative strain and the shear surface is a geometric abstraction.

children.label: speciation
children.definition: process that results inappearance of new species

children.label: spreading
children.definition: A process whereby new oceanic crust is formed by upwelling of magma at the center of mid-ocean ridges and by a moving-away of the new material from the site of upwelling at rates of one to ten centimeters per year.

children.label: strombolian eruption
children.definition: Eruption characterized by jetting of clots or \fountains\ of fluid, basaltic lava from a central crater

children.label: subduction
children.definition: The process of one lithospheric plate descending beneath another

children.label: tectonic process
children.definition: Processes related to the interaction between or deformation of rigid plates forming the crust of the Earth.

children.label: thermal shock weathering
children.definition: Propagation of fractures near the surface of solid rock due to expansion and contraction caused by temperature changes. Fractures typically propagate along surfaces close to and subparallel to the surface of the outcrop.

children.label: transform faulting
children.definition: A strike-slip fault that links two other faults or two other plate boundaries (e.g. two segments of a mid-ocean ridge). Transform faults often exhibit characteristics that distinguish them from transcurrent faults: (1) For transform faults formed at the same time as the faults they link, slip on the transform fault has equal magnitude at all points along the transform, slip magnitude on the transform fault can exceed the length of the transform fault, and slip does not decrease to zero at the fault termini. (2) For transform faults linking two similar features, e.g. if two mid-ocean ridge segments linked by a transform have equal spreading rates, then the length of the transform does not change as slip accrues on it.

children.label: turbidity current deposition
children.definition: Deposition from a turbulent, low concentration sediment-water mixture.

children.label: vulcanian eruption
children.definition: Eruption characterized by the explosive ejection of fragments of new lava, commonly incandescent when they leave the vent but either solid or too viscous to assume any appreciable degree of rounding during their flight through the air. With these there are often breadcrust bombs or blocks, and generally large proportions of ash

children.label: water erosion
children.definition: Erosion by clast impact or plucking by moving liquid water

children.label: weathering
children.definition: The process or group of processes by which earth materials exposed to atmospheric agents at or near the Earth's surface are changed in color, texture, composition, firmness, or form, with little or no transport of the loosened or altered material. Processes typically include oxidationhydration, and leaching of soluble constituents.

children.label: wind erosion
children.definition: Erosion by clast impact or plucking by moving air (wind)

children.label: favorable geological environment
children.definition: Identification of geological units or environments that are favorable or permissive for the occurrence of mineral deposits.

children.label: geochemical anomaly
children.definition: Area where geochemical properties (e.g. single or multiple element concentrations or isotope ratios) differ from surrounding areas and which may be the result of mineralisation.

children.label: geophysical anomaly
children.definition: Area where geophysical properties (e.g. radiometric, magnetic, electromagnetic, gravity) differ from surrounding areas and which may be the result of mineralisation.

children.label: identification of an anomalous area
children.definition: Area where geological, geophysical or geochemical properties are different from areas around and which might indicate the presence of a mineralizing process in the vicinity.

children.label: key geological features
children.definition: Identification of particular minerals or geological features which may indicate a possible mineralized area or accompany a mineralizing process

children.label: mineral occurrences
children.definition: Identification of occurrences of the target minerals as float (stone) or outcrop.

children.label: mineral reserve defined
children.definition: Definition of a three dimensional body of mineralization in sufficient technical detail and accompanied by an economic evaluation so that the estimated tonnage and grade can be classified as a mineral reserve. A Mineral Reserve is the economically mineable part of a Measured or Indicated Mineral Resource demonstrated by at least a Preliminary Feasibility Study.

children.label: mineral resource defined
children.definition: Work has been completed to identify a three dimensional zone of mineralization and estimate its tonnage and grade to the standard of a "mineral resource". Result allows definition of a 'Measured Mineral Resource' as defined by CIM (2010-11-27)

children.label: mineral resource indicated
children.definition: Identification of a three dimension zone of mineralization. This is done by augmenting surface work with a small number of drill holes. At this stage there is insufficient data to estimate tonnage and grade.

children.label: mineralized zone identified
children.definition: Identification by mapping and sampling of a two dimensional zone where the target minerals are found. This is done mainly by geological mapping and geochemical sampling and may include trenching and pitting.

children.label: negative feasibility study
children.definition: Completion of an economic evaluation of the mineral project at a level sufficient for a feasbility study with a resulting determination that extraction is not reasonably justified. A Feasibility Study is a comprehensive technical and economic study of the selected development option for a mineral project that includes appropriately detailed assessments of all factors necessary to determine at the time of reporting whether extraction is reasonably justified (economically mineable).

children.label: positive feasibility study
children.definition: Completion of an economic evaluation of the mineral project at a level sufficient for a feasibility study with a resulting determination that extraction is reaonably justfied. A Feasibility Study is a comprehensive technical and economic study of the selected development option for a mineral project that includes appropriately detailed assessments of all factors necessary to determine at the time of reporting whether extraction is reasonably justified (economically mineable).

children.label: detachment
children.definition: A regional-scale low-angle normal fault.

children.label: dextral
children.definition: Right-lateral separation sense, in plan view, the side opposite the observer appears displaced to the right.,

children.label: generic decollement
children.definition: A large-displacement (kilometers or tens of kilometers) shallowly dipping to subhorizontal fault or shear zone.

children.label: no movement sense
children.definition: The fault-parallel displacement is effectively zero, as in an extraction fault.

children.label: normal
children.definition: The hanging wall appears to have moved down relative to the footwall, dip of fault usually 45-90 degrees.

children.label: normal dextral
children.definition: The movement sense includes both normal and dextral components.

children.label: normal sinistral
children.definition: The movement sense includes both normal and sinistral components.

children.label: reverse
children.definition: The hanging wall appears to have moved down relative to the footwall, dip of fault usually greater than 45 degrees.

children.label: reverse dextral
children.definition: The movement sense includes both reverse and dextral components.

children.label: reverse sinistral
children.definition: The movement sense includes both reverse and sinistral components.

children.label: sinistral
children.definition: Left-lateral separation sense, in plan view, the side opposite the observer appears displaced to the left.

children.label: thrust
children.definition: Reverse fault with dip typically less than 45 degrees, horizontal compression, rather than vertical displacement is characteristic.

children.label: thrust decollement
children.definition: A regional-scale low-angle thrust fault.

children.label: dip separation sense
children.definition: A fault along which there is some separation parallel to the dip of the fault.

children.label: dip slip
children.definition: The net slip of the fault lies in the dip direction of the fault.

children.label: extraction
children.definition: A fault whose two sides have approached each other substantially in the direction perpendicular to the fault.

children.label: horizontal
children.definition: The fault is horizontal.

children.label: mixed extraction
children.definition: An extraction fault with some displacement within the fault plane.

children.label: oblique slip
children.definition: The net slip of the fault lies between the strike and dip directions of the fault, the slip vector rakes between 10 and 80 degrees in the plane of the fault.

children.label: pure extraction
children.definition: An extraction fault with no discernible displacement within the fault plane.

children.label: scissor
children.definition: A fault on which there is increasing offset or separation along the strike from an initial point of no offset, with reverse offset in the opposite direction.

children.label: strike separation sense
children.definition: A fault along which there is some separation parallel to the strike of the fault.

children.label: strike slip
children.definition: The net slip of the fault (slip vector) is parallel to the strike of the fault.

children.label: transcurrent
children.definition: A large scale strike-slip fault in which the fault surface is steeply inclined.

children.label: transform
children.definition: A variety of strike-slip fault along which the displacement suddenly stops or changes form, typically associated with mid-ocean ridges.

children.label: transpressional
children.definition: A fault along which strike-slip deformation is accompanied by a component of shortening transverse to the fault.

children.label: transtensional
children.definition: A fault along which strike-slip deformation is accompanied by a component of extension transverse to the fault.

children.label: wrench
children.definition: A strike slip fault in which the faut plane is more or less vertical.

children.label: detachment fault
children.definition: A regional-scale, large displacement, low-angle normal fault.

children.label: dextral strike slip fault
children.definition: Fault with right-lateral strike-parallel displacement component of slip vector more than 10 times the dip-parallel component of the slip vector at at least one location along the fault, and right-lateral displacement over more than half the mapped trace of the fault.

children.label: extraction fault
children.definition: A fault whose two sides have approached each other substantially in the direction perpendicular to the fault.

children.label: fault
children.definition: A discrete surface, or zone of discrete surfaces, with some thickness, separating two rock masses across which one mass has slid past the other and characterized by brittle deformation.

children.label: high angle fault
children.definition: Fault that dips at least 45 degrees over more than half of its recognized extent, for which slip or separation is not explicitly specified.

children.label: high angle normal fault
children.definition: Fault that dips at least 45 degrees over more than half of the recognized extent of the fault with the hanging wall displaced from a structurally higher position relative to footwall rocks.

children.label: high angle reverse
children.definition: Reverse fault that dips at least 45 degrees over more than half of its recognized extent, for which slip or separation is not explicitly specified.

children.label: horizontal fault
children.definition: Fault that dips less than 10 degrees over more than half the recognized extent of the fault.

children.label: left normal fault
children.definition: High angle fault with slip vector that has ratio of strike-parallel to dip-parallel displacement between 10 to 1 and 1 to 10 at at least one location along the mapped trace, with left-lateral strike-parallel component and normal dip-parallel component over at least half the mapped trace of the fault.

children.label: left reverse fault
children.definition: High angle fault with slip vector that has ratio of strike-parallel to dip-parallel displacement between 10 to 1 and 1 to 10 at at least one location along the mapped trace, with left-lateral strike-parallel component and reverse dip-parallel component over at least half the mapped trace of the fault.

children.label: low angle fault
children.definition: Fault that dips less than 45 degrees over more than half of the recognized extent of the fault.

children.label: low angle normal fault
children.definition: Fault that dips less than 45 degrees over more than half of the recognized extent of the fault with the hanging wall displaced from a structurally higher position relative to footwall rocks.

children.label: mixed extraction fault
children.definition: An extraction fault with some displacement within the fault plane.

children.label: normal fault
children.definition: Fault with dip-parallel displacement component of slip vector more than 10 times the strike-parallel component of the slip vector over more than half recognized extent of the fault, and for which the fault dips consistently in the same direction, and for which the hanging wall has been displaced down relative to the footwall.

children.label: oblique slip fault
children.definition: Fault with slip vector that has ratio of strike-parallel to dip-parallel displacement between 10 to 1 and 1 to 10 at at least one location along the mapped trace of the fault.

children.label: pure extraction fault
children.definition: An extraction fault with no discernible displacement within the fault plane.

children.label: reverse fault
children.definition: Fault with dip-parallel displacement component of slip vector more than 10 times the strike-parallel component of the slip vector at at least one location along the mapped trace of the fault, and the fault dips consistently in the same direction with the hanging wall displaced up relative to the footwall over at least half the mapped trace of the fault.

children.label: right normal fault
children.definition: High angle fault with slip vector that has ratio of strike-parallel to dip-parallel displacement between 10 to 1 and 1 to 10 at at least one location along the mapped trace, with right-lateral strike-parallel component and normal dip-parallel component of slip over at least half the mapped trace of the fault

children.label: right reverse fault
children.definition: High angle fault with slip vector that has ratio of strike-parallel to dip-parallel displacement between 10 to 1 and 1 to 10 at at least one location along the mapped trace, with a right-lateral strike-parallel component and reverse dip-parallel component of slip over at least half the mapped trace of the fault.

children.label: scissor fault
children.definition: A fault on which there is increasing offset or separation along the strike from an initial point of no offset, with the opposite sense of offset in the opposite direction.

children.label: sinistral strike slip fault
children.definition: Fault with left-lateral strike-parallel displacement component of slip vector more than 10 times the dip-parallel component of the slip vector at at least one location along the fault, and left-lateral displacement over more than half the mapped trace of the fault.

children.label: strike slip fault
children.definition: Fault with strike-parallel displacement component of slip vector more than 10 times the dip-parallel component of the slip vector at at least one location along the mapped trace of the fault.

children.label: thrust fault
children.definition: Fault that dips less than 45 degrees over more than half of the recognized extent of the fault, with a hanging wall displaced from a structurally deeper position relative to footwall rocks.

children.label: wrench fault
children.definition: A strike slip fault in which the fault plane dips at least 45 degrees over more than half of the recognized extent of the fault.

children.label: borehole cuttings observation
children.definition: Data based on interpretation of borehole cuttings

children.label: borehole geophysical log measurements
children.definition: Data based on interpretation of geophysical measurement obtained by borehole logging tools.

children.label: data from single published description
children.definition: Data are extracted from a publised description of the feature

children.label: digital conversion from published source
children.definition: Feature observation is based on published information, converted to a digital representation for database application

children.label: direct observation
children.definition: Feature observation is result of direct visual observation by a geologist

children.label: drill core observation
children.definition: Data collected through observation of a single drill core interval.

children.label: drill core observation estimated values
children.definition: Values for properties are estimated by observer.

children.label: drill core observation measured values
children.definition: Values for properties are measured using a device (compass, jacob staff, scintillometer, clinometer, ruler, etc.)

children.label: indirect method
children.definition: Feature observation based on inference from proxy observation

children.label: outcrop observation
children.definition: Data collected in field through direct observation of a single outcrop. Observer defines scope of 'single outcrop' - may be one point location, or averaged over an extended but connected) area, e.g. a single polygon on a map.  Direct observation may include observation using a remote camera (e.g. downhole viewer, submarine camera)

children.label: outcrop observation estimated values
children.definition: Values for properties are estimated by observer.

children.label: outcrop observation measured values
children.definition: Values for properties are measured using a device (compass, jacob staff, scintillometer, clinometer, ruler, etc.)

children.label: remotely sensed data
children.definition: Geologic unit or structure characterized based on remotely sensed data.

children.label: synthesis from multiple sources
children.definition: Feature observation is based on a synthesis of other observations by some compiler. The compiler may be the same individual that made the source observations.

children.label: synthesis of multiple outcrop observations
children.definition: Data are the result of synthesis from multiple direct observations, posibly by more than one observer

children.label: synthesis of multiple published descriptions
children.definition: Data are the result of synthesis from multiple published descriptions

children.label: anastomosing spaced cleavage
children.definition: spaced cleavage domains branch and rejoin, creating lens-shaped microlithons.

children.label: bedding fabric
children.definition: Fabric defined by textural or mineralogic variations in sediment produced by depositional processes. May be manifested by lamination structure within the sediment, or by layering in which the individual layers (beds) are bounded by discontinuities related to events in the depositional history.

children.label: bedding lamination structure
children.definition: A surface internal to the containing sediment mass defined by textural or mineralogical variation, produced by sediment deposition process, and reflecting the orientation of the original depositional surface. Syn Laminated structure (SLTTs 2004).

children.label: c fabric
children.definition: Ductile shear banding foliation defined by spaced, discrete planar zones of high strain less than 1mm thick. Commonly associated with a particle flattening ('S') fabric to form a mylonitic foliation.

children.label: cleavage
children.definition: A tectonic foliation in a rock characterized by a tendency for the rock to split along a regular set of parallel or sub-parallel closely spaced surfaces.
