children.definition: A schist that consists of more than 50 percent mica minerals, typically muscovite or biotite. Special type included to distinguish this common variety of schist.

children.label: migmatite
children.definition: Silicate metamorphic rock that is pervasively heterogeneous on a decimeter to meter scale that typically consists of darker and lighter parts; the darker parts usually exhibit features of metamorphic rocks whereas the lighter parts are of igneous-looking appearance.

children.label: monzodiorite
children.definition: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock consisting of sodic plagioclase (An0 to An50), alkali feldspar, hornblende and biotite, with or without pyroxene, and 0 to 5 percent quartz. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 9.

children.label: monzodioritic rock
children.definition: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock consisting of sodic plagioclase (An0 to An50), alkali feldspar, hornblende and biotite, with or without pyroxene, and 0 to 10 percent feldspathoid or 0 to 20 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction. Plagioclase to total feldspar ratio in the QAPF fraction is between 0.65 and 0.9. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 9, 9' and 9* as monzodiorite, foid-beaing monzodiorite, and quartz monzodiorite.

children.label: monzogabbro
children.definition: Monzogabbroic rock that contains between 0 an 5 percent quartz and no feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 9 .

children.label: monzogabbroic rock
children.definition: Gabbroid with a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio between 0.65 and 0.9. QAPF field 9, 9 prime and 9 asterisk

children.label: monzogranite
children.definition: Granite that has a plagiolcase to total feldspar ratio between 0.35 and 0.65. QAPF field 3b.

children.label: monzonite
children.definition: Monzonitic rock that contains 0-5 percent quartz and no feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF Field 8.

children.label: monzonitic rock
children.definition: Syenitoid with a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio between 0.35 and 0.65. Includes rocks in QAPF fields 8, 8*, and 8'.

children.label: mud
children.definition: Clastic sediment consisting of less than 30 percent gravel-size (2 mm) particles and with a mud-size to sand-size particle ratio greater than 1. More than half of the particles are of epiclastic origin.

children.label: mud size sediment
children.definition: Sediment consisting of less than 30 percent gravel-size (2 mm) particles and with a mud-size to sand-size particle ratio greater than 1. Clasts may be of any composition or origin.

children.label: mudstone
children.definition: Clastic sedimentary rock consisting of less than 30 percent gravel-size (2 mm) particles and with a mud to sand ratio greater than 1.

children.label: mylonitic rock
children.definition: Metamorphic rock characterised by a foliation resulting from tectonic grain size reduction, in which more than 10 percent of the rock volume has undergone grain size reduction. Includes protomylonite, mylonite, ultramylonite, and blastomylonite.

children.label: natural unconsolidated material
children.definition: Unconsolidated material known to have natural, ie. not human-made, origin.

children.label: non clastic siliceous sediment
children.definition: Sediment that consists of at least 50 percent silicate mineral material, deposited directly by chemical or biological processes at the depositional surface, or in particles formed by chemical or biological processes within the basin of deposition.

children.label: non clastic siliceous sedimentary material
children.definition: Sedimentary material that consists of at least 50 percent silicate mineral material, deposited directly by chemical or biological processes at the depositional surface, or in particles formed by chemical or biological processes within the basin of deposition.

children.label: non clastic siliceous sedimentary rock
children.definition: Sedimentary rock that consists of at least 50 percent silicate mineral material, deposited directly by chemical or biological processes at the depositional surface, or in particles formed by chemical or biological processes within the basin of deposition.

children.label: ooze
children.definition: Biogenic sediment consisting of less than 1 percent gravel-size (greater than or equal to 2 mm) particles, with a sand to mud ratio less than 1 to 9, and less than 50 percent carbonate minerals.

children.label: organic bearing mudstone
children.definition: Mudstone that contains a significant amount of organic carbon, typically kerogen. commonly finely laminated, brown or black in color.

children.label: organic rich sediment
children.definition: Sediment with color, composition, texture and apparent density indicating greater than 50 percent organic content by weight on a moisture-free basis.

children.label: organic rich sedimentary material
children.definition: Sedimentary material in which 50 percent or more of the primary sedimentary material is organic carbon.

children.label: organic rich sedimentary rock
children.definition: Sedimentary rock with color, composition, texture and apparent density indicating greater than 50 percent organic content by weight on a moisture-free basis.

children.label: orthogneiss
children.definition: A gneiss with mineralogy and texture indicating derivation from a phaneritic igneous rock protolith. Typically consists of abundant feldspar, with quartz, and variable hornblende, biotite, and muscovite, with a relatively homogeneous character.

children.label: packstone
children.definition: Carbonate sedimentary rock with discernible grain supported depositional texture, containing greater than 10 percent grains, and constituent particles are of intrabasinal origin; intergranular spaces are filled by matrix.

children.label: paragneiss
children.definition: A gneiss with mineralogy and texture indicating derivation from a sedimentary rock protolith. Typically consists of abundant quartz, mica, or calcsilicate minerals; aluminosilicate minerals or garnet commonly present. composition of rock tends to be more variable on a decimetric scale that in orthogneiss.

children.label: peat
children.definition: Unconsolidated organic-rich sediment composed of at least 50 percent semi-carbonised plant remains; individual remains commonly seen with unaided eye; yellowish brown to brownish black; generally fibrous texture; can be plastic or friable. In its natural state it can be readily cut and has a very high moisture content, generally greater than 90 percent. Liptinite to Inertinite ratio is less than one (Economic commission for Europe, committee on Sustainable Energy- United Nations (ECE-UN), 1998, International Classification of in-Seam Coals: Energy 19, 41 pp.)

children.label: pebble gravel size sediment
children.definition: Sediment containing greater than 30 percent pebble-size particles (2.0 -64 mm in diameter)

children.label: pegmatite
children.definition: Exceptionally coarse grained crystalline rock with interlocking crystals; most grains are 1cm or more diameter; composition is generally that of granite, but the term may refer to the coarse grained facies of any type of igneous rock;usually found as irregular dikes, lenses, or veins associated with plutons or batholiths.

children.label: peridotite
children.definition: Ultramafic rock consisting of more than 40 percent (by volume) olivine with pyroxene and/or amphibole and little or no feldspar. commonly altered to serpentinite. Includes rocks defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification as dunite, harzburgite, lherzolite, wehrlite, olivinite, pyroxene peridotite, pyroxene hornblende peridotite or hornblende peridotite.

children.label: phaneritic igneous rock
children.definition: Igneous rock in which the framework of the rock consists of individual crystals that can be discerned with the unaided eye. Bounding grain size is on the order of 32 to 100 microns. Igneous rocks with 'exotic' composition are excluded from this concept.

children.label: phonolite
children.definition: Phonolitoid in which the plagioclase to total feldspar ratio is less than 0.1. Rock consists of alkali feldspar, feldspathoid minerals, and mafic minerals.

children.label: phonolitic basanite
children.definition: Tephritoid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio between 0.5 and 0.9, and contains more than 10 percent normative (CIPW) olivine.

children.label: phonolitic foidite
children.definition: Foiditoid that contains less than 90 percent feldspathoid minerals in the QAPF fraction, and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio that is less than 0.5

children.label: phonolitic tephrite
children.definition: Tephritoid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio between 0.5 and 0.9, and contains less than 10 percent normative (CIPW) olivine.

children.label: phonolitoid
children.definition: Fine grained igneous rock than contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, between 10 and 60 percent feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio less than 0.5. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 11 and 12, and TAS field Ph.

children.label: phosphate rich sediment
children.definition: Sediment in which at least 50 percent of the primary and/or recrystallized constituents are phosphate minerals.

children.label: phosphate rich sedimentary material
children.definition: Sedimentary material in which at least 50 percent of the primary and/or recrystallized constituents are phosphate minerals.

children.label: phosphorite
children.definition: Sedimentary rock in which at least 50 percent of the primary or recrystallized constituents are phosphate minerals. Most commonly occurs as a bedded primary or reworked secondary marine rock, composed of microcrystalline carbonate fluorapatite in the form of lamina, pellets, oolites and nodules, and skeletal, shell and bone fragments.

children.label: phyllite
children.definition: Rock with a well developed, continuous schistosity, an average grain size between 0.1 and 0.5 millimeters, and a silvery sheen on cleavage surfaces. Individual phyllosilicate grains are barely visible with the unaided eye.

children.label: phyllonite
children.definition: Mylonitic rock composed largely of fine-grained mica that imparts a sheen to foliation surfaces; may have flaser lamination, isoclinal folding, and deformed veins, which indicate significant shearing. Macroscopically resembles phyllite, but formed by mechanical degradation of initially coarser rock.

children.label: porphyry
children.definition: Igneous rock that contains conspicuous phenocrysts in a finer grained groundmass; groundmass itself may be phaneritic or fine-grained.

children.label: pure calcareous carbonate sediment
children.definition: Carbonate sediment in which greater than 90 percent of the constituents are composed of one (or more) of the carbonate minerals in particles of intrabasinal origin, and a calcite (plus aragonite) to dolomite ratio greater than 1 to 1.

children.label: pure carbonate mudstone
children.definition: Mudstone that consists of greater than 90 percent carbonate minerals of intrabasinal orign in the mud fraction, and contains less than 10 percent allochems. The original depositional texture is preserved and fabric is matrix supported. Carbonate mudstone of Dunham (1962)

children.label: pure carbonate sediment
children.definition: Carbonate sediment in which greater than 90 percent of the constituents are composed of one (or more) of the carbonate minerals in particles of intrabasinal origin.

children.label: pure carbonate sedimentary rock
children.definition: Sedimentary rock in which greater than 90 percent of the primary and/or recrystallized constituents are carbonate minerals.

children.label: pure dolomitic sediment
children.definition: Carbonate sediment in which greater than 90 percent of the constituents are composed of one (or more) of the carbonate minerals in particles of intrabasinal origin, and a ratio of magnesium carbonate to calcite (plus aragonite) greater than 1 to 1.

children.label: pyroclastic material
children.definition: Fragmental igneous material that consists of more than 75 percent of particles formed by disruption as a direct result of volcanic action.

children.label: pyroclastic rock
children.definition: Fragmental igneous rock that consists of greater than 75 percent fragments produced as a direct result of eruption or extrusion of magma from within the earth onto its surface. Includes autobreccia associated with lava flows and excludes deposits reworked by epiclastic processes.

children.label: pyroxenite
children.definition: Ultramafic phaneritic igneous rock composed almost entirely of one or more pyroxenes and occasionally biotite, hornblende and olivine. Includes rocks defined modally in the ultramafic rock classification as olivine pyroxenite, olivine-hornblende pyroxenite, pyroxenite, orthopyroxenite, clinopyroxenite and websterite.

children.label: quartz alkali feldspar syenite
children.definition: Alkali feldspar syenitic rock that contains 5 to 20 percent quartz and no feldspathoid in the QAPF fraction. QAPF field 6*.

children.label: quartz alkali feldspar trachyte
children.definition: Alkali feldspar trachytic rock that contains and between 5 and 20 percent quartz mineral in the QAPF fraction. QAPF field 6*.

children.label: quartz anorthosite
children.definition: Anorthositic rock that contains between 5 and 20 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction. QAPF field 10*.

children.label: quartz diorite
children.definition: Dioritic rock that contains between 5 to 20 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction. QAPF field 10*.

children.label: quartz gabbro
children.definition: Gabbroic rock that contains between 5 and 20 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction. QAPF field 10*.

children.label: quartz latite
children.definition: Latitic rock that contains between 5 and 20 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction. QAPF field 8*.

children.label: quartz monzodiorite
children.definition: Monzodioritic rock that contains between 5 and 20 percent quartz.

children.label: quartz monzogabbro
children.definition: Monzogabbroic rock that contains between 5 and 20 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction. QAPF field 9*.

children.label: quartz monzonite
children.definition: Monzonitic rock that contains 5-20 percent quartz iin the QAPF fraction. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF Field 8*.

children.label: quartz rich igneous rock
children.definition: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock that contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals and contains greater than 60 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction.

children.label: quartz syenite
children.definition: Syenitic rock that contains between 5 and 20 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction. Defined modally in QAPF Field 7*.

children.label: quartz trachyte
children.definition: Trachytic rock that contains between 5 and 20 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction. QAPF field 7*.

children.label: quartzite
children.definition: Metamorphic rock consisting of greater than or equal to 75 percent quartz; typically granoblastic texture.

children.label: residual material
children.definition: Material of composite origin resulting from weathering processes at the Earth's surface, with genesis dominated by removal of chemical constituents by aqueous leaching. Miinor clastic, chemical, or organic input may also contribute. Consolidation state is not inherent in definition, but typically material is unconsolidated or weakly consolidated.

children.label: rhyolite
children.definition: rhyolitoid in which the ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is between 0.1 and 0.65.

children.label: rhyolitoid
children.definition: fine_grained_igneous_rock consisting of quartz and alkali feldspar, with minor plagioclase and biotite, in a microcrystalline, cryptocrystalline or glassy groundmass. Flow texture is common. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 2 and 3 or chemically in TAS Field R as rhyolite. QAPF normative definition is based on modal mineralogy thus: less than 90 percent mafic minerals, between 20 and 60 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction, and ratio of plagioclse to total feldspar is less than 0.65.

children.label: rock
children.definition: Consolidated aggregate of one or more EarthMaterials, or a body of undifferentiated mineral matter, or of solid organic material. Includes mineral aggregates such as granite, shale, marble; glassy matter such as obsidian; and organic material such a coal. Excludes unconsolidated materials.

children.label: rock salt
children.definition: Evaporite composed of at least 50 percent halite.

children.label: sand
children.definition: Clastic sediment in which less than 30 percent of particles are gravel (greater than 2 mm in diameter) and the sand to mud ratio is at least 1. More than half of the particles are of epiclastic origin.

children.label: sand size sediment
children.definition: Sediment in which less than 30 percent of particles are gravel (greater than 2 mm in diameter) and the sand to mud ratio is at least 1. composition or genesis of clasts not specified.

children.label: sandstone
children.definition: Clastic sedimentary rock in which less than 30 percent of particles are greater than 2 mm in diameter (gravel) and the sand to mud ratio is at least 1.

children.label: sapropel
children.definition: Jelly like organic rich sediment composed of plant remains, usually algal. Liptinite to Inertinite ratio is greater than one (Economic commission for Europe, committee on Sustainable Energy- United Nations (ECE-UN), 1998, International Classification of in-Seam Coals: Energy 19, 41 pp.)

children.label: schist
children.definition: Foliated phaneritic metamorphic rock with well developed, continuous schistosity, meaning that greater than 50 percent of the rock by volume is mineral grains with a thin tabular, lamellar, or acicular prismatic crystallographic habit that are oriented in a continuous planar or linear fabric.

children.label: sediment
children.definition: Unconsolidated material consisting of an aggregation of particles transported or deposited by air, water or ice, or that accumulated by other natural agents, such as chemical precipitation, and that forms in layers on the Earth's surface. Includes epiclastic deposits.

children.label: sedimentary material
children.definition: Material formed by accumulation of solid fragmental material deposited by air, water or ice, or material that accumulated by other natural agents such as chemical precipitation from solution or secretion by organisms. Includes both sediment and sedimentary rock. Includes epiclastic deposits. All stated composition criteria are based on the mineral/ compound material (GeoSciML term)/particulate fraction of the material, irrespective of porosity or the pore-fluid. No distinctions are made based on porosity or pore fluid composition (except organic rich sediment in which liquid hydrocarbon content may be considered).

children.label: sedimentary rock
children.definition: Rock formed by accumulation and cementation of solid fragmental material deposited by air, water or ice, or as a result of other natural agents, such as precipitation from solution, the accumulation of organic material, or from biogenic processes, including secretion by organisms. Includes epiclastic deposits.

children.label: serpentinite
children.definition: Rock consisting of more than 75 percent serpentine-group minerals, eg. antigorite, chrysotile or lizardite; accessory chlorite, talc and magnetite may be present; derived from hydration of ferromagnesian silicate minerals such as olivine and pyroxene.

children.label: shale
children.definition: Laminated mudstone that will part or break along thin, closely spaced layers parallel to stratification.

children.label: silicate mud
children.definition: Mud size sediment that consists of less than 50 percent carbonate minerals.

children.label: silicate mudstone
children.definition: Mudstone that contains less than 10 percent carbonate minerals.

children.label: siliceous ooze
children.definition: ooze that consists of more than 50 percent siliceous skeletal remains

children.label: silt
children.definition: Mud that consists of greater than 50 percent silt-size grains.

children.label: siltstone
children.definition: Mudstone that contains detectable silt. (see comments)

children.label: skarn
children.definition: Metasomatic rock consisting mainly of Ca-, Mg-, Fe-, or Mn-silicate minerals, which are free from or poor in water. Typically formed at the contact between a silicate rock or magma and a carbonate rock.

children.label: slate
children.definition: compact, fine grained rock with an average grain size less than 0.032 millimeter and a well developed schistosity (slaty cleavage), and hence can be split into slabs or thin plates.

children.label: spilite
children.definition: Altered basic to intermediate composition fine-grained igneous rock in which the feldspar is partially or completely composed of of albite, typically accompanied by chlorite, calcite, quartz, epidote, prehnite, and low-tempaerature hydrous crystallization products. Preservation of eruptive volcanic features is typical.

children.label: syenite
children.definition: Syenitic rock that contains between 0 and 5 percent quartz and no feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction. Defined modally in QAPF Field 7.

children.label: syenitic rock
children.definition: Syenitoid with a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio between 0.1 and 0.35. Includes rocks in QAPF fields 7, 7*, and 7'.

children.label: syenitoid
children.definition: Phaneritic crystalline igneous rock with M less than 90, consisting mainly of alkali feldspar and plagioclase; minor quartz or nepheline may be present, along with pyroxene, amphibole or biotite. Ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is less than 0.65, quartz forms less than 20 percent of QAPF fraction, and feldspathoid minerals form less than 10 percent of QAPF fraction. Includes rocks classified in QAPF fields 6, 7 and 8 and their subdivisions.

children.label: syenogranite
children.definition: Granite that has a plagiolcase to total feldspar ratio between 0.10 and 0.35. QAPF field 3a.

children.label: tephra
children.definition: Unconsolidated pyroclastic material in which greater than 75 percent of the fragments are deposited as a direct result of volcanic processes and the deposit has not been reworked by epiclastic processes. Includes ash, lapilli tephra, bomb tephra, block tephra and unconsolidated agglomerate.

children.label: tephrite
children.definition: Tephritoid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio greater than 0.9, and contains less than 10 percent normative (CIPW) olivine.

children.label: tephritic foidite
children.definition: Foiditoid that contains less than 90 percent feldspathoid minerals in the QAPF fraction, and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio that is greater than 0.5, with less than 10 percent normative olivine

children.label: tephritic phonolite
children.definition: Phonolitoid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio between 0.1 and 0.5. Broadly corresponds to TAS tephriphonolite of TAS field U3.

children.label: tephritoid
children.definition: Fine grained igneous rock than contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, between 10 and 60 percent feldspathoid mineral in the QAPF fraction and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio greater than 0.5. Includes rocks classified in QAPF field 13 and 14 or chemically in TAS field U1 as basanite or tephrite.

children.label: tholeiitic basalt
children.definition: Tholeiitic basalt is defined here to contain 2 pyroxene phases and interstitial quartz or tridymite or cristobalite in the groundmass. Pyroxene (augite and orthopyroxene or pigeonite) and calcium-rich plagioclase are common phenocryst minerals. Olivine may also be a phenocryst, and when present, may have rims of pigeonite. Only in tholeiitic basalt is olivine in reaction relationship with melt. Interstitial siliceous residue may be present, and is often glassy. Tholeiitic basalt is relatively poor in sodium. This category includes most basalts of the ocean floor, most large oceanic islands, and continental flood basalts such as the Columbia River Plateau.

children.label: tonalite
children.definition: Granitoid consisting of quartz and intermediate plagioclase, usually with biotite and amphibole. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF field 5; ratio of plagioclase to total feldspar is greater than 0.9.

children.label: trachyte
children.definition: Trachytoid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio between 0.1 and 0.35, between 0 and 5 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction, and no feldspathoid minerals. QAPF field 7.

children.label: trachytic rock
children.definition: Trachytoid that has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio between 0.1 and 0.35. QAPF fields 7, 7', and 7*.

children.label: trachytoid
children.definition: Fine grained igneous rock than contains less than 90 percent mafic minerals, less than 10 percent feldspathoid mineral and less than 20 percent quartz in the QAPF fraction and has a plagioclase to total feldspar ratio less than 0.65. Mafic minerals typically include amphibole or mica; typically porphyritic. Includes rocks defined modally in QAPF fields 6, 7 and 8 (with subdivisions) or chemically in TAS Field T as trachyte or latite.

children.label: travertine
children.definition: Biotically or abiotically precipitated calcium carbonate, from spring-fed, heated, or ambient-temperature water. May be white and spongy, various shades of orange, tan or gray, and ranges to dense, banded or laminated rock. Macrophytes, bryophytes, algae, cyanobacteria and other organisms often colonize the surface of travertine and may be preserved, to produce the porous varieties.

children.label: tuff breccia agglomerate or pyroclastic breccia
children.definition: Pyroclastic rock in which greater than 25 percent of particles are greater than 64 mm in largest dimension. Includes agglomerate, pyroclastic breccia of Gillespie and Styles (1999)

children.label: tuffite
children.definition: Rock consists of more than 50 percent particles of indeterminate pyroclastic or epiclastic origin and less than 75 percent particles of clearly pyroclastic origin. commonly the rock is laminated or exhibits size grading. (based on LeMaitre et al. 2002; Murawski and Meyer 1998).

children.label: ultrabasic igneous rock
children.definition: Igneous rock with less than 45 percent SiO2.

children.label: ultramafic igneous rock
children.definition: Igneous rock that consists of greater than 90 percent mafic minerals.

children.label: unconsolidated material
children.definition: compoundMaterial composed of an aggregation of particles that do not adhere to each other strongly enough that the aggregate can be considered a solid in its own right.

children.label: wacke
children.definition: Clastic sandstone with more than 10 percent matrix of indeterminate detrital or diagenetic nature. Matrix is mud size silicate minerals (clay, feldspar, quartz, rock fragments, and alteration products).

children.label: bed
children.definition: The smallest formal lithostratigraphic unit; usually a distinctive lithic entity which can be distinguished from adjacent rocks by one or more physical characteristics.

children.label: complex
children.definition: A lithostratigraphic unit composed of diverse types of any class or classes of rock (sedimentary; igneous; metamorphic); and characterized by irregularly mixed lithology or by hightly complicated structure relations to the extent that the original sequence of the component rocks may be obscured and the individual rocks or rock sequence cannot be readily mapped.

children.label: formation
children.definition: A body of rock identified by lithic characteristics and stratigraphic position; it is usually but not necessarily tabular and is mappable at the Earth's surface or traceable in the subsurface.

children.label: group
children.definition: A group is the lithostratigraphic unit next higher in rank to either subgroup or formation. A groups may consist of two or more subgroups or two or more formations or a combination of both.

children.label: lithodeme
children.definition: A body of predominantly intrusivehighly deformed and/or highly metamorphosed rock; distinguished and delimited on the basis of rock characteristics.

children.label: megasequence
children.definition: A succession of strata comprising two or more supersequences. A large-scale sequence-stratigraphic unit deposited during one distinct phase of basin evolution; separated by major unconformities that mark a change in fundamental basin-controlling processes.

children.label: member
children.definition: A formal lithostratigraphic unit next in rank below a formation; and always part of a formation. It is a named entity within a formation because it possesses characteristics distinguishing it from adjacent parts of the formation.

children.label: not specified
children.definition: unit is not part of a defined stratigraphic hierarchy.

children.label: sequence
children.definition: A genetically related succession of strata bounded by unconformites or their correlative conformable contacts; and typically having a thickness of 10-100 metres.

children.label: subgroup
children.definition: A subgroup is the lithostratigraphic unit next higher in rank to formation. A subgroup usually consists of several formations.

children.label: suite
children.definition: A formal lithodemic unit next higher in rank to lithodeme. It comprises two or more associated lithodemes of the same class (e.g.; plutonic; metamorphic).

children.label: supergroup
children.definition: A supergroup is a formal assemblage of related or superposed groups or of groups and formations

children.label: supersequence
children.definition: A succession of strata comprising two or more sequences

children.label: supersuite
children.definition: A formal lithodemic unit next higher in rank to suite. It comprises two or more suites having a degree of natural relationship to one another

children.label: additional quantities in place
children.definition: Quantities should only be classified as Additional Quantities in Place where no technically feasible projects have been identified that could lead to the extraction of any of these quantities.

children.label: approved for development
children.definition: Approved for Development requires that all approvals/contracts are in place, and capital funds have been committed. Construction and installation of project facilities should be underway or due to start imminently.

children.label: commercial projects
children.definition: Commercial Projects have been confirmed to be technically, economically and socially feasible.

children.label: development not viable
children.definition: Development not Viable is used where a technically feasible project can be identified, but it has been assessed as being of insufficient potential to warrant any further data acquisition activities or any direct efforts to remove commercial contingencies.

children.label: development on hold
children.definition: Development On Hold is used where a project is considered to have at least a reasonable chance of achieving commerciality (i.e. there are reasonable prospects for eventual economic extraction), but where there are currently major non-technical contingencies (e.g. environmental or social issues) that need to be resolved before the project can move towards development.

children.label: development pending
children.definition: Development Pending is limited to those projects that are actively subject to projectspecific technical activities, such as acquisition of additional data (e.g. appraisal drilling) or the completion of project feasibility studies and associated economic analyses designed to confirm project commerciality and/or to determine the optimum development scenario or mine plan.

children.label: development unclarified
children.definition: Development Unclarified is appropriate for projects that are still in the early stages of technical and commercial evaluation (e.g. a recent new discovery), and/or where significant further data acquisition will be required, in order to make a meaningful assessment of the potential for a commercial development, i.e. there is currently insufficient basis for concluding that there are reasonable prospects for eventual economic extraction.

children.label: exploration projects
children.definition: Project identiifed that has not advanced enought to categorize further.

children.label: justified for development
children.definition: Justified for Development requires that the project has been demonstrated to be technically feasible and commercially viable, and there must be a reasonable expectation that all necessary approvals/contracts for the project to proceed to development will be forthcoming.

children.label: non‐commercial projects
children.definition: Non‐Commercial Projects include those that are at an early stage of evaluation in addition to those that are considered unlikely to become commercially feasible developments within the foreseeable future.

children.label: on production
children.definition: On Production is used where the project is actually producing/extracting and selling one or more commodities to market as at the Effective Date of the evaluation.

children.label: potentially commercial projects
children.definition: Potentially Commercial Projects are expected to be developed in the foreseeable future, in that the quantities are assessed to have reasonable prospects for eventual economic extraction, but technical and/or commercial feasibility has not yet been confirmed

children.label: always
children.definition: All instances of the observed entity have this property value

children.label: approximate
children.definition: Specified value is approximate

children.label: common
children.definition: Reported property value is commonly observered

children.label: equalTo
children.definition: Reported property value is the observered value

children.label: greaterThan
children.definition: Reported property value is lower bound

children.label: lessThan
children.definition: Reported property value is upper bound

children.label: never
children.definition: Reported property value is never observed

children.label: rare
children.definition: Reported property value is rarely observed

children.label: sometimes
children.definition: Reported property value is observed occasionally

children.label: broader generic relation
children.definition: This relationship identifies the link between a source class term and target members or species. This type of relationship is often called 'IsA'. A simple way to apply the test for validity described above is to formulate the statement '[narrower term] is a [broader term].' This relationship is also amenable to a logical \all-and-some\ test. An example that passes this test is that some members of the class succulent plants are known as cacti and that all cacti, by definition and regardless of context, are succulent plants. An example that fails the test is that some members of the class 'desert plants' are known as 'cacti', some, but not all, 'cacti' are 'desert plants'. These terms should therefore be assigned to different hierarchies in the controlled vocabulary, and both terms should be assigned to the same content object when indexing a work on \cacti as desert plants..\ Inverse relationship 'narrower generic term' is not included in this

children.label: broader term
children.definition: Link from a source term to a superordinate (more general or parent) target term. General hierarchical relationship, more specific subtype relationships (generic, instance, and whole-part) should be used whenever possible.

children.label: during
children.definition: Beginning and end of source interval are both after the beginning of the target interval and before the end of the target interval.

children.label: instance of
children.definition: This relationship identifies the link between an individual instance of a category, often a proper name, and a term for a general category of things or events, expressed by a common noun. This type of relationship is also known as an 'IsA' relationship. Example: Alps/mountain regions In the above example, the Alps are assigned to subordinate positions in a hierarchy, yet they are neither kinds nor parts of mountain regions, but represent specific examples or instances.

children.label: interval finishes
children.definition: Source and target interval share same ending instant (moment in Allen and Ferguson, 1994 terms), and target interval beginning is before source interval beginning.

children.label: interval starts
children.definition: Source and target intervals have same starting instant (moment in Allen and Ferguson, 1994 terms), and end of target interval is after end of source interval.

children.label: lexical variant
children.definition: Lexical variants differ from synonyms in that synonyms are different terms for the same concept, while lexical variants are different word forms for the same expression. These forms may derive from spelling or grammatical variation or from abbreviated formats. E.g. radar antennas / antennas, radar, Romania / Rumania / Roumania, ground water / ground-water / groundwater, online / on-line pediatrics / paediatrics

children.label: most specific subsuming term
children.definition: First role is term, second role is most specific subsuming term. Special case of 'broader term' thesaurus relationship.

children.label: near synonym
children.definition: Near-synonyms are terms whose meanings are generally regarded as different, but which are treated as equivalents for the purposes of a controlled vocabulary. The extent to which terms are treated as near-synonyms depends in large measure upon the domain covered by the controlled vocabulary and its size. Near-synonyms may include antonyms or represent points on a continuum. Examples: sea water / salt water [variant terms] meteors / meteorites / meteoroids [points on a continuum] smoothness / roughness [antonyms] For each of these sets of near synonyms, a vocabulary developer might decide to designate one of the terms as the preferred term with the understanding that it will retrieve all content described by the other terms as well. As a general rule, terms should be treated as near-synonyms only in subject areas that are peripheral to the domain of the controlled vocabulary. When concepts can be distinguished in the controlled vocabulary domain with sufficient precision to justify their representation as separate terms, they should be individually defined and retained. If two concepts cannot be consistently and reliably differentiated from each otherhowever, a term for one concept should be selected as the preferred term and a USE reference made from the other.

children.label: part of
children.definition: This relationship covers situations in which one concept (source) is inherently included in another (target), regardless of context, so that the terms can be organized into logical hierarchies, with the whole treated as a broader term. This relationship can be applied to several types of term, the three types enumerated below are not intended to be exhaustive. For time interval concepts (ordinal eras) (Allen and Ferguson, 1994), this relationship subsumes ‘During’, ‘Interval starts’, and ‘Interval finishes’. Examples: brain/central nervous system/nervous system, Ottawa/Ontario/Canada, regiment/battalion/military division/army, Cambrian/Paleozoic/Phanerozoic.

children.label: related term
children.definition: \This relationship covers associations between terms that are neither equivalent nor hierarchical, yet the terms are semantically or conceptually associated to such an extent that the link between them should be made explicit in the controlled vocabulary, on the grounds that it may suggest additional terms for use in indexing or retrieval. \ \As a general guideline, whenever one term is used, the other should always be implied within the common frames of reference shared by the users of the controlled vocabulary. Moreover, one of the terms is often a necessary component in any explanation or definition of the other, the term cells, for example, forms a necessary part of the definition of cytology.\

children.label: synonym
children.definition: \Synonyms are terms whose meanings are regarded as the same or nearly the same in a wide range of contexts. True synonyms are rare in natural language. Although the terms are interchangeable in many circumstances, usage can vary as a result of such factors as level of formality, professional vs. lay context, or pejorative vs. neutral vs. complimentary connotation.\

children.label: target follows source
children.definition: Relationship for partial ordering of concepts in a vocabulary that has some sort of ordering, for example a time scale consisting of time ordinal eras (geologic time scale). Equivalent to 'Intervals meet' relation of Allen and Ferguson (1994). Intervals are conterminous. End of source interval is same time instant (moment in terms of Allen and Ferguson, 1994) as beginning of target interval.

children.label: covered
children.definition: Covered mining waste storage at ground level

children.label: surface
children.definition: Mining waste storage at open-sky environment (ground level)

children.label: underground
children.definition: Mining waste storage at underground environment

children.label: underwater
children.definition: Mining waste deposited at sea or lake floor (e.g. sea bed mining)

children.label: False
children.definition: Hazardous materials are not known to exist in collection.

children.label: True
children.definition: Hazardous materials are known to exist in collection.

children.label: False
children.definition: Type specimens are not known to exist in collection.

children.label: True
children.definition: Type specimens are known to exist in collection.

keywords.label: nggdpp_collection_types
keywords.definition: Terms denoting the type/function of collection items in the National Digital Catalog

children.label: ndc_collection
children.definition: Item that represents a logical collection of physical data items managed by an organization contributing to the National Digital Catalog. These are core metadata items for which we expect to find full metadata describing the collection and a method of accessing the contents in the collection.

children.label: ndc_folder
children.definition: Denotes a ScienceBase Item that functions as an organizational folder within the National Digital Catalog.

children.label: ndc_organization
children.definition: Item that represents a contributing organization. Used to set permissions in ScienceBase to allow management access by members of the organization.

keywords.label: Observational Data Model (Version 2)
keywords.definition:
Observation Data Model (ODM2) Vocabularies
See https://doi.org/10.1016/j.envsoft.2016.01.010 for paper on ODM2 and http://vocabulary.odm2.org/ for vocabularies.

children.label: cruise
children.definition: A specialized form of an expedition action that involves an ocean-going vessel. Cruise actions are typically parents to other related Actions.

children.label: dataRetrieval
children.definition: The act of retrieving data from a datalogger deployed at a monitoring site.

children.label: derivation
children.definition: The act of creating results by deriving them from other results.

children.label: equipmentDeployment
children.definition: The act of placing equipment that will not make observations at or within a sampling feature. Actions involving the deployment of instruments should use the more specific term Instrument deployment.

children.label: equipmentMaintenance
children.definition: The act of performing regular or periodic upkeep or servicing of field or laboratory equipment. Maintenance may be performed in the field, in a laboratory, or at a factory maintenance center.

children.label: equipmentProgramming
children.definition: The act of creating or modifying the data collection program running on a datalogger or other equipment deployed at a monitoring site.

children.label: equipmentRetrieval
children.definition: The act of recovering a piece of equipment that made no observations from a deployment at a sampling feature or other location. For instruments, the more specific term Instrument retrieval should be used.

children.label: estimation
children.definition: The act of creating results by estimation or professional judgement.

children.label: expedition
children.definition: A field visit action in which many sites are visited over a continguous period of time, often involving serveral investigators, and typically having a specific purpose.  Expedition actions are typically parents to other related Actions.

children.label: fieldActivity
children.definition: A generic, non-specific action type performed in the field at or on a sampling feature.

children.label: genericNonObservation
children.definition: A generic, non-specific action type that does not produce a result.

children.label: instrumentCalibration
children.definition: The act of calibrating an instrument either in the field or in a laboratory. The instrument may be an in situ field sensor or a laboratory instrument.  An instrument is the subclass of equipment that is capable of making an observation to produce a result.

children.label: instrumentDeployment
children.definition: The act of deploying an in situ instrument or sensor that creates an observation result.  This term is a specific form of the Observation actions category of actions, which is the only category of actions that can produce observation results.

children.label: instrumentRetrieval
children.definition: The act of recovering an in situ instrument (which made observations) from a sampling feature. This action ends an instrument deployment action.

children.label: observation
children.definition: The general act of making an observation. This term should be used when a Result is generated but the more specific terms of Instrument deployment or Specimen analysis are not applicable.

children.label: simulation
children.definition: The act of calculating results through the use of a simulation model.

children.label: siteVisit
children.definition: A field visit action in which a single site is visited for one or more other possible actions (i.e., specimen collection, equipment maintenance, etc.).  Site visit actions are typically parents to other related actions.

children.label: specimenAnalysis
children.definition: The analysis of a specimen ex situ using an instrument, typically in a laboratory, for the purpose of measuring properties of that specimen.

children.label: specimenCollection
children.definition: The collection of a specimen in the field.

children.label: specimenFractionation
children.definition: The process of separating a specimen into multiple different fractions or size classes.

children.label: specimenPreparation
children.definition: The processing of a specimen collected in the field to produce a sample suitable for analysis using a particular analytical procedure.

children.label: specimenPreservation
children.definition: The act of preserving a specimen collected in the field to produce a sample suitable for analysis using a particular analytical procedure.

children.label: submersibleLaunch
children.definition: The act of deploying a submersible from a vessel or ship.

children.label: average
children.definition: The values represent the average over a time interval, such as daily mean discharge or daily mean temperature.

children.label: bestEasySystematicEstimator
children.definition: Best Easy Systematic Estimator BES = (Q1 +2Q2 +Q3)/4. Q1, Q2, and Q3 are first, second, and third quartiles. See Woodcock, F. and Engel, C., 2005: Operational Consensus Forecasts.Weather and Forecasting, 20, 101-111. (http://www.bom.gov.au/nmoc/bulletins/60/article_by_Woodcock_in_Weather_and_Forecasting.pdf) and Wonnacott, T. H., and R. J. Wonnacott, 1972: Introductory Statistics. Wiley, 510 pp.

children.label: categorical
children.definition: The values are categorical rather than continuous valued quantities.

children.label: confidenceInterval
children.definition: In statistics, a confidence interval (CI) is a type of interval estimate of a statistical parameter. It is an observed interval (i.e., it is calculated from the observations), in principle different from sample to sample, that frequently includes the value of an unobservable parameter of interest if the experiment is repeated. How frequently the observed interval contains the parameter is determined by the confidence level or confidence coefficient.

children.label: constantOverInterval
children.definition: The values are quantities that can be interpreted as constant for all time, or over the time interval to a subsequent measurement of the same variable at the same site.

children.label: continuous
children.definition: A quantity specified at a particular instant in time measured with sufficient frequency (small spacing) to be interpreted as a continuous record of the phenomenon.

children.label: cumulative
children.definition: The values represent the cumulative value of a variable measured or calculated up to a given instant of time, such as cumulative volume of flow or cumulative precipitation.

children.label: incremental
children.definition: The values represent the incremental value of a variable over a time interval, such as the incremental volume of flow or incremental precipitation.

children.label: maximum
children.definition: The values are the maximum values occurring at some time during a time interval, such as annual maximum discharge or a daily maximum air temperature.

children.label: median
children.definition: The values represent the median over a time interval, such as daily median discharge or daily median temperature.

children.label: minimum
children.definition: The values are the minimum values occurring at some time during a time interval, such as 7-day low flow for a year or the daily minimum temperature.

children.label: mode
children.definition: The values are the most frequent values occurring at some time during a time interval, such as annual most frequent wind direction.

children.label: sporadic
children.definition: The phenomenon is sampled at a particular instant in time but with a frequency that is too coarse for interpreting the record as continuous. This would be the case when the spacing is significantly larger than the support and the time scale of fluctuation of the phenomenon, such as for example infrequent water quality samples.

children.label: standardDeviation
children.definition: The values represent the standard deviation of a set of observations made over a time interval. Standard deviation computed using the unbiased formula SQRT(SUM((Xi-mean)^2)/(n-1)) are preferred. The specific formula used to compute variance can be noted in the methods description.

children.label: standardErrorOfMean
children.definition: The standard error of the mean (SEM) quantifies the precision of the mean. It is a measure of how far your sample mean is likely to be from the true population mean. It is expressed in the same units as the data.

children.label: standardErrorOfTheMean
children.definition: The standard error of the mean (SEM) quantifies the precision of the mean. It is a measure of how far your sample mean is likely to be from the true population mean. It is expressed in the same units as the data.

children.label: unknown
children.definition: The aggregation statistic is unknown.

children.label: variance
children.definition: The values represent the variance of a set of observations made over a time interval. Variance computed using the unbiased formula SUM((Xi-mean)^2)/(n-1) are preferred. The specific formula used to compute variance can be noted in the methods description.

children.label: actionAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or qualifying comment about an Action

children.label: actionGroup
children.definition: A group of actions such as those that are part of a cruise, expedition, experiment, project, etc.

children.label: categoricalResultValueAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or data qualifying comment applied to a data value from a categorical Result

children.label: dataSetAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or qualifying comment about a DataSet

children.label: equipmentAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or qualifying comment about a piece of Equipment

children.label: measurementResultValueAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or data qualifying comment applied to a data value from a measurement Result

children.label: methodAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or qualifiying comment about a Method

children.label: organizationAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or qualifiying comment about an Organization

children.label: personAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or qualifying comment about a Person

children.label: personGroup
children.definition: A group of people such as a research team, project team, etc.

children.label: pointCoverageResultValueAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or data qualifying comment applied to a data value from a point coverage Result

children.label: profileResultValueAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or data qualifying comment applied to a data value from a profile Result

children.label: resultAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or qualifying comment about a Result

children.label: samplingFeatureAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or qualifiying comment about a SamplingFeature

children.label: sectionResultValueAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or data qualifying comment applied to a data value from a section Result

children.label: siteAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or qualifying comment about a Site

children.label: siteGroup
children.definition: A group of sites such as a transect, station, observatory, monitoring collection, etc.

children.label: specimenAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or qualifying comment about a Specimen

children.label: specimenGroup
children.definition: A group of specimens such as an analysis batch, profile, experiment, etc.

children.label: spectraResultValueAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or data qualifying comment applied to a data value from a spectra Result

children.label: timeSeriesResultValueAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or data qualifying comment applied to a data value from a time series Result

children.label: trajectoryResultValueAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or data qualifying comment applied to a data value from a trajectory Result

children.label: transectResultValueAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or data qualifying comment applied to a data value from a transect Result

children.label: valueGroup
children.definition: A group of data values such as those from a profile, analysis, spectra, publication table, dataset, incident reports, etc.

children.label: variableAnnotation
children.definition: An annotation or qualifying comment about a Variable

children.label: greaterThan
children.definition: The value is known to be greater than the recorded value.

children.label: lessThan
children.definition: The value is known to be less than the recorded value.

children.label: nonDetect
children.definition: The value was reported as a non-detect. The recorded value represents the level at which the anlalyte can be detected.

children.label: notCensored
children.definition: The reported value is not censored.

children.label: presentButNotQuantified
children.definition: The anlayte is known to be present, but was not quantified. The recorded value represents the level below which the analyte can no longer be quantified.

children.label: unknown
children.definition: It is unknown whether the data value as reported is censored.

children.label: accuracy
children.definition: The degree of closeness of a measurement of a quantity to that quantity's true value.

children.label: methodDetectionLimit
children.definition: The minimum concentration of a substance that can be distinguished from the absence of that substance within a stated confidence limit (generally 1%) given a particular analytical method.

children.label: physicalLimitLowerBound
children.definition: This describes a numeric value below which measured values should be considered suspect. This numeric value should be empirically derived.

children.label: physicalLimitUpperBound
children.definition: This describes a numeric value above which measured values should be considered suspect. This numeric value should be empirically derived.

children.label: precision
children.definition: The degree to which repeated measurements under unchanged conditions show the same results.

children.label: reportingLevel
children.definition: The smallest concentration of analyte that can be reported by laboratory.

children.label: multiTimeSeries
children.definition: A Dataset that contains multiple time series Results. This corresponds to the YAML Observations Data Archive (YODA) multi-time series profile.

children.label: multiVariableSpecimenMeasurements
children.definition: A dataset that contains multiple measurement Results derived from Specimens. This corresponds to the YAML Observations Data Archive (YODA) specimen time series profile.

children.label: other
children.definition: A set of Results that has been grouped into a Dataset because they are logically related. The group does not conform to any particular profile.

children.label: singleTimeSeries
children.definition: A Dataset that contains a single time series Result. This corresponds to the YAML Observations Data Archive (YODA) singe time series profile.

children.label: specimenTimeSeries
children.definition: A dataset that contains multiple measurement Results derived from Specimens. This corresponds to the YAML Observations Data Archive (YODA) specimen time series profile.

children.label: fieldCampaign
children.definition: A sampling event conducted in the field during which instruments may be deployed and during which samples may be collected. Field campaigns typically have a focus such as characterizing a particular environment, quantifying a particular phenomenon, answering a particular research question, etc. and may last for hours, days, weeks, months, or even longer.

children.label: monitoringProgram
children.definition: Environmental monitoring that is conducted according to a formal plan that may reflect the overall objectives of an organization, references specific strategies that help deliver the objectives and details of specific projects or tasks, and that contains a listing of what is being monitored, how that monitoring is taking place, and the time-scale over which monitoring should take place.

children.label: project
children.definition: A collaborative enterprise, involving research or design, the is carefully planned to achieve a particular aim.

children.label: AHD
children.definition: Australian Height Datum. Height datum used for standardised elevations across Australia. The datum surface is defined as that which passes through mean sea level at the 30 specified tide gauges and through points at zero AHD height vertically below the other basic junction points.

children.label: EGM96
children.definition: EGM96 (Earth Gravitational Model 1996) is a geopotential model of the Earth consisting of spherical harmonic coefficients complete to degree and order 360.

children.label: MSL
children.definition: Mean Sea Level

children.label: NAVD88
children.definition: North American Vertical Datum of 1988

children.label: NGVD29
children.definition: National Geodetic Vertical Datum of 1929

children.label: Unknown
children.definition: The vertical datum is unknown

children.label: antenna
children.definition: An electrical device that converts electric power into radio waves and vice versa.

children.label: automaticLevel
children.definition: A survey level that makes use of a compensator that ensures the line of sight remains horizontal once the operator has roughly leveled the instrument.

children.label: battery
children.definition: A device consisting of one or more electrochemical cells that convert stored chemical energy into electrical energy.

children.label: cable
children.definition: Two or more wires running side by side and bonded, twisted, or braided together to form a single assembly.

children.label: camera
children.definition: A device used to create photographic images

children.label: chargeRegulator
children.definition: An electroinic device that limits the rate at which electric current is added to or drawn from electric batteries.

children.label: datalogger
children.definition: An electronic device that records data over time or in relation to location either with a built in instrument or sensor or via external instruments and sensors.

children.label: electronicDevice
children.definition: A generic electronic device

children.label: enclosure
children.definition: A cabinet or box within which electrical or electronic equipment are mounted to protect them from the environment.

children.label: fluorometer
children.definition: A device used to measure paramters of flouroescence, including its intensity and wavelength distribution of emission spectrum after excitation by a certain spectrum of light.

children.label: globalPositioningSystemReceiver
children.definition: A device that accurately calculates geographical location by receiving information from Global Positioning System satellites.

children.label: interface
children.definition: A device used to couple multiple other devices.

children.label: laboratoryInstrument
children.definition: Any type of equipment, apparatus or device designed, constructed and refined to use well proven physical principles, relationships or technology to facilitate or enable the pursuit, acquisition, transduction and storage of repeatable, verifiable data, usually consisting of sets numerical measurements made upon otherwise unknown, unproven quantities, properties, phenomena, materials, forces or etc.

children.label: levelStaff
children.definition: A graduate wooden, fiberglass, or aluminum rod used to determine differences in elevation.

children.label: mast
children.definition: A pole that supports sensors, instruments, or measurement peripherals.

children.label: measurementTower
children.definition: A free standing tower that supports measuring instruments or sensors.

children.label: multiplexer
children.definition: A device that selects one of several analog or digital input signals and forwards the selected input into a single line.

children.label: powerSupply
children.definition: An electronic device that supplies electric energy to an electrical load. The primary function of a power supply is to convert one form of electrical energy to another (e.g., solar to chemical).

children.label: pressureTransducer
children.definition: A sensor that measures pressure, typically of gases or liquids.

children.label: radio
children.definition: A device that transfers information via electromagnetic signals through the atmosphere or free space.

children.label: sampler
children.definition: A device used to collect specimens for later ex situ analysis.

children.label: sensor
children.definition: A device that detects events or changes in quantities and provides a corresponding output, generally as an electrical or optical signal.

children.label: solarPanel
children.definition: A photovoltaic module that is electrically connected and mounted on a supporting structure.  Used to generate and supply electricity.

children.label: stormBox
children.definition: An enclosure used to protect electronic equipment used for stormwater sampling.

children.label: totalStation
children.definition: An electronic and optical instrument used in modern surveying and building construction.  A total station is an electronic theodoloite integrated with an electronic distance meter to read slope distances from the instrument to a particular point.

children.label: tripod
children.definition: A portable, three-legged frame used as a platform for supporting the weight and maintaining the stability of some other object. Typically used as a data collection platform to which sensors are attached.

children.label: turbidimeter
children.definition: A water quality sensor that monitors light reflected off the particles suspended in water.

children.label: waterQualitySonde
children.definition: A water quality monitoring instrument having multiple attached sensors.

children.label: air
children.definition: Specimen collection of ambient air or sensor emplaced to measure properties of ambient air.

children.label: equipment
children.definition: An instrument, sensor or other piece of human-made equipment upon which a measurement is made, such as datalogger temperature or battery voltage.

children.label: gas
children.definition: Gas phase specimen or sensor emplaced to measure properties of a gas.

children.label: habitat
children.definition: A habitat is an ecological or environmental area that is inhabited by a particular species of animal, plant, or other type of organism.

children.label: ice
children.definition: Sample collected as frozen water or sensor emplaced to measure properties of ice.

children.label: liquidAqueous
children.definition: Specimen collected as liquid water or sensor emplaced to measure properties of water in sampled environment.

children.label: liquidOrganic
children.definition: Specimen collected as an organic liquid.

children.label: mineral
children.definition: Specimen collected as a mineral.

children.label: notApplicable
children.definition: There is no applicable sampled medium.

children.label: organism
children.definition: Data collected about a species at organism level.

children.label: other
children.definition: Other.

children.label: particulate
children.definition: Specimen collected from particulates suspended in a paticulate-fluid mixture. Examples include particulates in water or air.

children.label: regolith
children.definition: The entire unconsolidated or secondarily recemented cover that overlies more coherent bedrock, that has been formed by weathering, erosion, transport and/or deposition of the older material. The regolith thus includes fractured and weathered basement rocks, saprolites, soils, organic accumulations, volcanic material, glacial deposits, colluvium, alluvium, evaporitic sediments, aeolian deposits and ground water. Everything from fresh rock to fresh air.

children.label: rock
children.definition: Specimen collected from a naturally occuring solid aggregate of one or more minerals.

children.label: sediment
children.definition: Specimen collected from material broken down by processes of weathering and erosion and subsequently transported by the action of wind, water, or ice, and/or by the force of gravity acting on the particles. Sensors may also be emplaced to measure sediment properties.

children.label: snow
children.definition: Observation in, of or sample taken from snow.

children.label: soil
children.definition: Specimen collected from soil or sensor emplaced to measure properties of soil. Soil includes the mixture of minerals, organic matter, gasses, liquids, and organisms that make up the upper layer of earth in which plants grow.

children.label: tissue
children.definition: Sample of a living organism's tissue or sensor emplaced to measure property of tissue.

children.label: unknown
children.definition: The sampled medium is unknown.

children.label: vegetation
children.definition: The plants of an area considered in general or as communities, but not taxonomically.

children.label: cruise
children.definition: A method for performing a cruise action.

children.label: dataRetrieval
children.definition: A method for retrieving data from a datalogger deployed at a monitoring site.

children.label: derivation
children.definition: A method for creating results by deriving them from other results.

children.label: equipmentDeployment
children.definition: A method for deploying a piece of equipment that will not make observations at a sampling feature.

children.label: equipmentMaintenance
children.definition: A method for performing periodic upkeep or servicing of field or laboratory equipment. Maintenance may be performed in the field, in a laboratory, or at a factory maintenance center.

children.label: equipmentProgramming
children.definition: A method for creating or modifying the data collection program running on a datalogger or other equipment deployed at a monitoring site.

children.label: equipmentRetrieval
children.definition: A method for retrieving equipment from a sampling feature at which or on which it was deployed.

children.label: estimation
children.definition: A method for creating results by estimation or professional judgement.

children.label: expedition
children.definition: A method for performing an expedition action.

children.label: fieldActivity
children.definition: A method for performing an activity in the field at or on a sampling feature.

children.label: genericNonObservation
children.definition: A method for completing a non-specific action that does not produce a result.

children.label: instrumentCalibration
children.definition: A method for calibrating an instrument either in the field or in the laboratory.

children.label: instrumentContinuingCalibrationVerification
children.definition: A method for verifying the instrument or meter calibration by measuring a calibration standard of known value as if it were a sample and comparing the measured result to the calibration acceptance criteria listed in the Standard Operating Procedure.

children.label: instrumentDeployment
children.definition: A method for deploying an instrument to make observations at a sampling feature.

children.label: instrumentRetrieval
children.definition: A method for retrieving or recovering an instrument that has been deployed at a smpling feature.

children.label: observation
children.definition: A method for creating observation results. This term should be used when a Result is generated but the more specific terms of Instrument deployment or Specimen analysis are not applicable.

children.label: simulation
children.definition: A method for creating results by running a simulation model.

children.label: siteVisit
children.definition: A method for performing a site visit action.

children.label: specimenAnalysis
children.definition: A method for ex situ analysis of a specimen using an instrument, typically in a laboratory, for the purpose of measuring properties of a specimen.

children.label: specimenCollection
children.definition: A method for collecting a specimen for ex situ analysis.

children.label: specimenFractionation
children.definition: A method for separating a specimen into multiple different fractions or size classes.

children.label: specimenPreparation
children.definition: A method for processing a specimen collected in the field to produce a sample suitable for analysis using a particular analytical procedure.

children.label: specimenPreservation
children.definition: A method for preserving a specimen either in the field or in a laboratory prior to ex situ analysis.

children.label: submersibleLaunch
children.definition: A method for launching a submersible from a vessel or ship.

children.label: unknown
children.definition: The method type is unknown.

children.label: boolean
children.definition: A boolean type is typically a logical type that can be either "true" or "false".

children.label: controlledList
children.definition: A predefined list of strings that a user can select from.

children.label: floatingPointNumber
children.definition: A floating-point number represents a limited-precision rational number that may have a fractional part.

children.label: integer
children.definition: An integer data type can hold a whole number, but no fraction. Integers may be either signed (allowing negative values) or unsigned (nonnegative values only).

children.label: string
children.definition: An array of characters including letters, digits, punctuation marks, symbols, etc.

children.label: bad
children.definition: A quality assessment has been made and enough of the data quality objectives have not been met that the observation has been assessed to be of bad quality.

children.label: good
children.definition: A quality assessment has been made and all data quality objectives have been met.

children.label: marginal
children.definition: A quality assessment has been made and one or more data quality objectives has not been met. The observation may be suspect and has been assessed to be of marginal quality.

children.label: none
children.definition: No data quality assessment has been made.

children.label: unknown
children.definition: The quality of the observation is unknown.

children.label: cites
children.definition: Use to indicate a relation to the work that the resource is citing/quoting.

children.label: compiles
children.definition: One to many relationship that denotes that the one source resource has been assembled from the target resources through a process of integration and harmonization (as opposed to simple aggregation).

children.label: continues
children.definition: Use to indicate the resource is a continuation of the work referenced by the related identifier.

children.label: documents
children.definition: Use to indicate the relation to the work which is documentation.

children.label: hasPart
children.definition: Use to indicate the resource is a container of another resource.

children.label: isAttachedTo
children.definition: Used to indicate that one entity is attached to another. For example this term can be used to express the fact that a piece of equipment is attached to a related piece of equipment.

children.label: isChildOf
children.definition: Used to indicate that one entity is an immediate child of another entity. For example, this term can be used to express the fact that an instrument deployment Action is the child of a site visit Action.

children.label: isCitationFor
children.definition: Used to indicate the relationship between a Citation and the entity for which it is the Citation.

children.label: isCitedBy
children.definition: Use to indicate the relation to a work that cites/quotes this data.

children.label: isCompiledBy
children.definition: Use to indicate the resource or data is compiled/created by using another resource or dataset.

children.label: isContinuedBy
children.definition: Use to indicate the resource is continued by the work referenced by the related identifier.

children.label: isDerivedFrom
children.definition: Used to indicate the relation to the works from which the resource was derived.

children.label: isDocumentedBy
children.definition: Use to indicate the work is documentation about/explaining the resource referenced by the related identifier.

children.label: isIdenticalTo
children.definition: Used to indicate the relation to a work that is identical to the resource.

children.label: isNewVersionOf
children.definition: Use to indicate the resource is a new edition of an old resource, where the new edition has been modified or updated.

children.label: isOriginalFormOf
children.definition: Use to indicate the relation to the works which are variant or different forms of the resource.

children.label: isPartOf
children.definition: Use to indicate the resource is a portion of another resource.

children.label: isPreviousVersionOf
children.definition: Use to indicate the resource is a previous edition of a newer resource.

children.label: isReferencedBy
children.definition: Use to indicate the resource is used as a source of information by another resource.

children.label: isRelatedTo
children.definition: Used to indicate that one entity has a complex relationship with another entity that is not a simple, hierarchical parent-child relationship. For example, this term can be used to express the fact that an instrument cleaning Action is related to an instrument deployment action even though it may be performed as part of a separate site visit.

children.label: isRetrievalfor
children.definition: Use to indicate the action is a retrieval of a previous deployment.

children.label: isReviewedBy
children.definition: Used to indicate that the work is reviewed by another resource.

children.label: isSourceOf
children.definition: Used to indicate the relation to the works that were the source of the resource.

children.label: isSupplementedBy
children.definition: Use to indicate the relation to the work(s) which are supplements of the resource.

children.label: isSupplementTo
children.definition: Use to indicate the relation to the work to which the resource is a supplement.

children.label: isVariantFormOf
children.definition: Use to indicate the resource is a variant or different form of another resource, e.g. calculated or calibrated form or different packaging.

children.label: references
children.definition: Use to indicate the relation to the work which is used as a source of information of the resource.

children.label: Reviews
children.definition: Used to indicate that the work reviews another resource.

children.label: wasCollectedAt
children.definition: Used to indicate that one entity was collected at the location of another entity. For example, thirs term can be used to express the fact that a specimen SamplingFeature was collected at a site SamplingFeature.

children.label: categoryObservation
children.definition: A single ResultValue for a single Variable, measured on or at a single SamplingFeature, using a single Method.

children.label: countObservation
children.definition: A single ResultValue for a single Variable, counted on or at a single SamplingFeature, using a single Method, and having a specific ProcessingLevel.

children.label: measurement
children.definition: A single ResultValue for a single Variable, measured on or at a SamplingFeature, using a single Method, with specific Units, and having a specific ProcessingLevel.

children.label: pointCoverage
children.definition: A series of ResultValues for a single Variable, measured on or at a single SamplingFeature, using a single Method, with specific Units, having a specific ProcessingLevel, with a fixed ValueDateTime, but measured over varying X,Y locations, where X and Y are horizontal coordinates.

children.label: profileCoverage
children.definition: A series of ResultValues for a single Variable, measured on or at a single SamplingFeature, using a single Method, with specific Units, having a specific ProcessingLevel, but measured over multiple locations along a depth profile with only one varying location dimension (e.g., Z, where Z is depth). ValueDateTime may be fixed or controlled.

children.label: sectionCoverage
children.definition: A series of ResultValues for a single Variable, measured on or at a single SamplingFeature, using a single Method, with specific Units, having a specific ProcessingLevel, but measured over varying X (horizontal) and Z (depth) coordinates. ValueDateTime may be fixed or controlled.

children.label: spectraCoverage
